title: baptist belief about god
message:
JANUARY: WEEK 1

BAPTIST BELIEF ABOUT GOD

HYMN: BH 20 O Worship the King

SCRIPTURE: Genesis 1:1-5

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  1. Explain four peculiar attributes of God.
  2. Analyse how their knowledge of the nature of God can help them to live a lifestyle that is beneficial to the society as expected of them by God.

ICE BREAKING PERIOD: Brainstorming

Has God revealed Himself to humanity, or are we left to wonder and speculate about His identity? Has He introduced Himself to His creation? If so, how?

Facilitator's Opening Remarks

The Baptist's belief about God is based on the Bible. Biblical testimonies about God are quite revealing. The eternal true God reveals Himself to us as the Father, Son and Holy Spirit, with distinct personal attributes but without division of nature, essence, or being. The Bible portrays in abundance countless number of God's natural and moral qualities which describe who God is and how He has worked through history. Our focus in this lesson is on four of such qualities of God which represent part of our beliefs about God as the people called "Baptists". An exposure into this will increase our knowledge of God and give us a better understanding of ourselves in line with His purpose for us to become like Him.

EDUCATION/INTERACTION PERIOD

  1. God as the Creator

    In accordance with the Scriptures, Baptists believe that there is one and only one living and true God who is the Creator of the heavens and the earth while man is His creation. God is the Maker, Preserver and Ruler of all things (Genesis 1:1__2:15; Psalm 102:25). We believe the eternal triune God reveals Himself to us as Father, Son, and Holy Spirit, with distinct personal attributes, but without division of nature, essence, or being. To Him we owe the highest love, reverence, and obedience.

    Sharing Time: If you truly see yourself as a child of God who remains the ultimate Creator, what responsibility does this privilege place on you?

  2. God as Omnipotent, Omnipresent and Omniscient

    Baptists strongly believe that God is omnipotent (all powerful); omnipresent (God is present everywhere at the same time); and omniscient (God knows everything). These attributes of God underscore the reality of His care, concern and security for us. We equally believe that God knows everything about us. His eyes cover everywhere and we are safe in His powerful hands (Psalm 139:1-8). Throughout the Scripture, we see the evidence of God's presence, power, and knowledge manifesting in His dealings with mankind.

    Sharing Time: How does God's omniscient nature affect our lives in relation to personal holiness and righteousness?

  3. God Is Love

    Divine love is God's benevolent care and concern for His creatures. Baptists hold that God's love is an everlasting love (Jeremiah 31:3, John 13:1). His love is unchanging, unfailing and steadfast (Deuteronomy 7:12; Lamentations 3:22). God's love is selfless, sacrificial, self-giving, self denying love (John 10:17-18). God's sacrificial love is fully, maximally and uniquely demonstrated in the incarnation of His Son, Jesus Christ. So, God continues to demonstrate this love to us unconditionally; everyone who has truly experienced this love holds it a duty to demonstrate same to fellow human beings through caring, giving and mutual forgiveness. Throughout the Bible, we see the evidence of unconditional love which was ultimately fulfilled in the giving of His Son, Jesus to pay the penalty of our sins.

    Sharing Time: Someone confesses "I find it difficult to forgive when people offend me." How will you describe the spiritual condition of this person?

  4. God Is Holy

    Baptists believe that God is infinitely holy. Holiness depicts the being and the doing of God as sound, whole, complete and perfect (Isaiah 6:3; Revelation 3:7, 4:8). The holy nature of God demands that whoever will worship Him acceptably should take after Him in holiness and righteousness. This word "holy" speaks of His transcendence, or the fact that He is infinitely exalted above all of creation. Hence, His command to us to be perfect (Matthew 5:48; 1 Peter 1:15-16). The demand to be perfect is a definite command to desire to live a holy life of excellence as we face temptations on daily basis.

    Sharing Time: How can you satisfy the demand of the Scripture to be holy with the realities of life?

Facilitator's Closing Remarks

The God of the Bible is one God who manifests Himself as God the Father, God the Son and God the Holy Spirit. Although God manifests Himself in three persons, He is still one. Man by instinct believes in the existence of God for he is born with a universal belief in a Supreme Being who created and sustains all things in love, holiness, presence, power and knowledge. It is only a fool that will deny the existence of God (Psalm 53:1). That is why the Bible nowhere attempts to prove the existence of God but rather points to His unquestionable Being. Right from the first verse of the Bible (Genesis 1:1) to the end; throughout the whole Bible, God is seen to BE not dependent on anyone or anything to exist.

Activity Period

  1. List five values and virtues in our society you are to live out.
  2. Discuss how biblically correct these assertions are (a) "God is love" (b) "Love is not God".

title: baptist belief about the scripture
message:
JANUARY: WEEK 2

BAPTIST BELIEF ABOUT THE SCRIPTURE

HYMN: BH 179 Holy Bible, Book Divine

SCRIPTURE: 2 Timothy 3:16-17

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  1. Explain some bases for accepting the Scripture as the inspired Word of God.
  2. List some characteristics of inerrancy regarding the Scriptures.
  3. Mention the books that make up the canonised Bible.

ICE BREAKING PERIOD: Discussion

The Baptists down the centuries have always been referred to as `the People of the Book'. This is as a result of the Church's strong and ardent belief in the Bible. For the Baptists, the Holy Bible is regarded as the basis for all acts and lifestyles. All practices and polities are determined by the Bible. In view of the current wave of worldliness and secularity threatening the devotional life of many Christians, will you as a disciple still consider the contemporary Baptist men and women as `the People of the Book?

Facilitator\'s Opening Remarks

Baptists believe that the Holy Bible, otherwise known as "the Holy Book" or "the Holy Writ" is the final authority in matters of faith. This is as a result of the contents of the Book which copiously reveal the principles by which God relates, interacts with, and judges man. Our focus at this juncture is to shed light on few of our beliefs about the Scripture specifically in areas of its inspiration, inerrancy, authority and canonicity. A reminder of this nature will definitely enrich our spiritual growth, enlighten our mind to the importance of the Bible and eventually enhance the edification of the body of Christ.

EDUCATION/INTERACTION PERIOD

  1. The Scriptures as Inerrant

    The word "inerrant" implies the absence of error. Baptists believe that all Scriptures are void of errors and mistakes simply because of the fact that they are the products of divine inspiration (Psalm 18:30; Proverbs 30:5). Since God who Himself remains the centre of truth supervised the writing including the words and phrases used, the Baptists confidently hold the Bible free of any error. However, we must note that the degree of inerrancy in relation to the Bible is highly achieved and greatly appreciated when interpreted within the peculiar context of the passage and the intention of the writer (Psalm 119:138).

    Sharing Time: What would you do if doing what God says in the Bible will cost you a valued relationship, a valued position, a valued possession, or even if it costs your life?

  2. The Scriptures as Inspired Word of God

    It is the belief of Baptists that the Old and New Testaments were written by the inspiration of God. A reference to the Bible as "inspired" means that the infinite God chose human channels, human intellect and experience, through which to pour out His truth to all men. It further indicates that it is "God breathed". The belief of Baptists is that all Scriptures is breathed out by God into the hearts of the chosen men and women who wrote the different books of the Bible (2 Timothy 3:16; 2 Peter 1:20-21). In other words, the Word of God is not of human origin but originates from God Himself.

    Sharing Time: Ponder on this: "There are elements of mystery in the way the Bible was brought to us." Should this assertion lead us to reject its claim or rejoice at its truth?

  3. The Scriptures as the Sole and Final Authority

    Baptists hold that the Holy Bible is the `sole and final authority' in matters of faith, polity, policies and all realms of Christian life. This belief emanated from our convictions about the inerrancy and the inspirational nature of the Bible. In view of this, Baptists, therefore accept the Holy Bible as the yardstick for determining the rightness and the wrongness of deeds, doctrines and practices. One mark of the authority of the Bible is its sufficiency; indicating that the sixty-six books of the Bible contains enough truth for handling all our religious and secular needs. Another mark of authority of the Bible is to be seen in its certainty. Every issue raised in the Word of God is characterised with the highest degree of certainty. In this vein, Baptists consider the Holy Bible as the sole and final authority for all saving knowledge, faith and obedience (Psalm 119:89).

    Sharing Time: Understanding something of the nature, what witnesses do we have for the authenticity of Scripture?

  4. The Canonicity of the Scriptures

    The word "Canonicity" means a rule or standard of measurement (Galatians 6:16). Its application to the Scriptures refers to the Bible's literary limits; that is, the authoritative body of writings with precise literary limits. The canonicity of the Scriptures answers the questions "which types of books of the Bible were considered inspired, and for what reasons were they included in the Holy Bible?" For Baptists, we believe that the canonical books (authoritative inspired books of the Bible) are sixty-six (39 books of the OT and 27 books of the NT). The grounds and the criteria for acceptance of the books are the veracity of the historical facts, Jesus' acknowledgement of the facts in the writings and the authenticity of the apostolic authorship of the books (Matthew 4:7; 5:17; Luke 4:16-21; 11:51; Colossians 4:16; Revelations 22:18). Other writings which lack these qualifications such as Apocrypha and pseudepigrapha, which are accepted by a few other branches of the Church are regarded by Baptists as uninspired and, therefore, should not form part of the canonical books.

    Sharing Time: Apart from the sixty-six canonised books of the Bible which we believe to be authoritative, mention two non-canonised books which other denominations use today.

Facilitator's Closing Remarks

The Scriptures which were originally written to convey the mind of God undoubtedly remain the very Word of God. The divine inspiration that birthed these books makes them inerrant. As for Baptists, the entire Scripture is believed to be a perfect treasure of divine instruction which has God as its Author and salvation as its end. No wonder we consider it to be totally true and trustworthy. As Baptists, the Bible should remain the supreme standard by which all our conducts, creeds, and religious opinions are tried.

Activity Period

  1. What are the practical ways to resolve the contradictions on the issues of faith and works as discussed in both Romans 3:24; 4:1-3 and James 2:14-18, 24, 26?

title: baptist belief about god's purpose of grace
message:
JANUARY: WEEK 3

BAPTIST BELIEF ABOUT GOD'S PURPOSE OF GRACE

HYMN: BH 200 Grace Greater than Our Sins

SCRIPTURE: 2 Samuel 9:1-13

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  1. Define the concept of `Grace'.
  2. Use different synonyms for the same word and
  3. Explain two main purposes of God's grace in the lives of the disciples.

ICE BREAKING PERIOD: Case Study

A young Christian lady was led by the Holy Spirit to witness to a group of people in Masifa town in Osun State. In the course of sharing the gospel, a young passer-by interrupted, shouted on the Christian lady and tore her Bible. In response to people's pressure on the lady to take a legal action against the young man, the lady said "I am not bothered, I started with preaching the gospel of grace in this community; will I now end it with the law?" What is your view on the response of this lady?

Facilitator's Opening Remarks

The Old Testament, several times, used different terms such as `goodness', `mercy', `favour', `kindness', `steadfast love' and `covenant love' to describe the concept of biblical grace. These words are popularly called the `Grace-Words' though they do not contain the word `Grace" (Moffatt). As for the New Testament, the subject of grace involves forgiveness, salvation, repentance, regeneration and the love of God. Aptly put, GRACE means `God's Riches At Christ's Expense' (from the acronym: G-R-A-C-E). Every disciple must be grateful to God for being a beneficiary of His grace even as we remind ourselves today of this unique privilege.

EDUCATION/INTERACTION PERIOD

  1. By His Grace We Are Given What We Don't Deserve

    God's grace is commonly referred to as unmerited favour. Baptist Churches all over the world believe that all benefits and blessings, both natural and spiritual, are the products of God's grace. We believe that all our righteous acts and deeds are like filthy rags and that the best of us are children of disobedience by nature, birth and practice. No human being, however good or great, deserves God's blessing (Ephesians 2:1-3). However, as God's choice through His grace, we who have responded to the call into grace have become partakers of His many blessings of salvation, love, forgiveness, favour, kindness, justification, glorification, etc. It is through God's grace that we have access to this undeserved and unmerited favour. It is similar to the experience of Mephibosheth as reflected in our text for this lesson. David's question in 2 Samuel 9:1-3 whether there was anyone still left of the house of Saul to whom he could show kindness for Jonathan's sake reflects God's gracious desire for us.

    Sharing Time: List five blessings you do not deserve but God graciously gives to you.

  2. By His Grace We Are Not Given What We Deserve

    Biblically, grace is something that is unmerited and undeserved. It is not something a person can lay claim to as his right. Baptists believe we receive from God what we do not deserve or should earn in any way. Paul says that our salvation is a gift of God and something that we could never achieve on our own merit. We deserve nothing from God neither does He owe us anything. The good that we experience is a result of the grace of God (Ephesians 2:5). God favours, or gives us good things that we do not deserve and can never earn. Two kinds of grace can be seen in the way God relates with humans. Common grace refers to the sovereign grace which God bestows on all mankind regardless of their spiritual standing before Him, while saving grace is that special dispensation of grace whereby God sovereignly bestows unmerited divine assistance upon His elect for their regeneration and sanctification.

    Sharing Time: List five things you do not deserve but God gave you because of His grace.

  3. By His Grace We Are Saved

    Baptists believe that the all-inclusive, most significant purpose and chief end of God's grace is our salvation. It is by the act of grace, through the death of our Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ, that every born again child of God receives newness of life as against a life of sin, self, death and hell. It is on this principle of grace that God released His only begotten Son and on the act of same grace that the Son voluntarily surrendered Himself to die on the cross. Baptists accept that faith is the means by which we encounter salvation. But ever before faith came into the picture, the act, virtue and quality that actualised it is grace. "For it is by grace you have been save through faith __ and this not from yourselves, it is the gift of God." (Ephesians 2:8)

    Sharing Time: Read and compare these two passages John 3:16 and Ephesians 2:8.

    1. Which of these two actually saved us, GRACE or LOVE? Why do you say so?
    2. What is the role love played in bringing about our salvation?
  4. By His Grace We Are What We Are

    Every Baptist believes that all that he/she is and has are purely by acts of grace. Baptists are proud to identify with Paul in His conviction and declaration that "...by the grace of God, I am what I am." (1 Corinthians 15:10). We believe that we were once dead in our trespasses, but as we received God's grace we became alive in Him. God graciously lavishes on us the fruits of the Holy Spirit for us to grow into Christlikeness. We are also given charismatic gifts, spiritual gifts of grace, for building up His Church (Romans 12:6). Indeed, the conviction that has held us together over the years as Baptists has been "we are what we are by His grace".

    Sharing Time: There is a hidden note of warning in Paul's statement, "…and His grace to me was not without effect" (1 Corinthians 15:10). What could make God's grace in our lives ineffective? How do we prevent that from happening?

Facilitator's Closing Remarks

Not only is God merciful, He is also gracious. God's grace is simply God's unmerited favour towards us. We do not deserve it; we did nothing to earn it. Again, it is grounded in God's character. Because God is merciful and loving and gracious, He offers us salvation. He does not offer us His salvation because of who we are; He offers it to us because of who He is. That means that because of God's mercy He does not punish us the minute we sin, and because of His grace, He offers us forgiveness of sins, salvation from the penalty of sin and eternal life. It is the strong belief of Baptists to pattern their lives after Jesus' example by relating with God and fellow human beings on the basis of grace.

Activity Period

  1. Give some examples of how Christians can relate with one another on the basis of grace in the context of employee-employer relationship (considering salary and emolument, hours of resumption, and hours of closing in the place of work).
  2. In view of God's preference and act of dealing with man based on GRACE, rather than LAW; how will you describe a Christian who relates with God and man based on law (Exodus 20:8) rather than grace (Hebrews 10:25)?

title: baptist belief about salvation
message:
JANUARY: WEEK 4

BAPTIST BELIEF ABOUT SALVATION

HYMN: BH 192 Are You Washed in the Blood?

SCRIPTURE: John 1:1-15

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  1. Explain the term `Salvation'.
  2. Analyse the three stages of salvation.
  3. Formulate definition of salvation and evaluate the genuineness of their salvation experience.

ICE BREAKING PERIOD: Case Study

A story was told of a man who was drowning as a result of a terrible storm at sea. After his struggles were futile, an expert swimmer plunged himself into the sea to rescue him. As soon as the drowning man opened his eyes and discovered he had been rescued, he asked: "Who saved me?" When his deliverer, lying on the deck was pointed out, he struggled to lift himself up and crawled to the man; put his arms around his feet and feebly, he cried: "I'm your servant, I'm your servant." He felt that he could never do enough for him. Permit me to ask this question: How much can you do for the Lord Jesus who saved you from judgment, condemnation and death?

Facilitator's Opening Remarks

As Baptists we identify with the evangelical movement of the Christian faith, and we affirm that salvation from sin is obtained through the grace of God. We believe that salvation is the redemption of the whole man and it is given to all who accept the offer of Jesus Christ as Saviour and Lord, who obtained eternal redemption for believers by His own blood. In its broadest sense, salvation includes regeneration, justification, sanctification and glorification. There is no salvation outside personal faith in Jesus Christ as Lord. Our attention will be on this all-important gift that God lavished on mankind which cannot be earned by good works or obtained on the basis of human merit. A reminder of these salient issues about salvation as discussed below is needed for healthy life of the church and the benefit of the whole world.

EDUCATION/INTERACTION PERIOD

  1. Conversion: A Gateway to Salvation

    Baptists affirm the necessity of conversion for every person on earth. Conversion is a process by which humans are saved. It is a reversal from Satan's ways to embrace God. According to Baptists, conversion may seem to be gradual and systematic as seen in the experience of Timothy (1Timothy 1:3-6). It can also be dramatic and sudden as observed in the life of Saul who became Paul (Acts 9:1-6). Baptists regard the doctrine of conversion as highly important and as the only remedy for the spiritual condition of mankind who naturally inherited sin (Romans 5:19); was born a sinner (Psalm 51:5); became a sinner by choice (Isaiah 53:6) and got addicted to sin by practice (Ecclesiastes 7:20). Conversion into Christianity takes place at the point a penitent sinner makes a lifetime sincere commitment to trade off his sins in exchange for Christ's righteousness.

    Sharing Time: Which of the two kinds of conversion experience (gradual/systematic or dramatic/sudden) did you have? Share your response with others in the group.

  2. Justification: Salvation as Past

    Baptists view salvation as an act which was given and received in the past. This belief is predicated on biblical texts such as "...by grace you have been saved" (Ephesians 2:8); "who has saved us and called us..." (2 Timothy 1:9) and "He saved ... He saved us through the washing..." (Titus 3:5). The ground for this belief is based on the life and death of Christ, which happened at a fixed period in history (1 Timothy 1:15; Hebrews 2:10; 5:9; 12:2). Thus, the basis on which salvation is given is by the completed atoning work of Christ, though our experience of salvation is far from being finished. However, the fact remains that every born-again child of God appropriated Christ's death when he/she believed in and confessed Jesus. Consequently, he/she became justified having been rescued from the penalty of sin (death). Justification is the activity of God which liberates a person from the guilt of sin and imputes the righteousness of God to mankind.

    Sharing Time: "How are you working out your salvation is a complete work through the death of our Saviour and Lord Jesus Christ, but its experience is far from being finished," Discuss.

  3. Sanctification: Salvation as Present

    Salvation, according to Baptists, is also viewed as a present action and an ongoing spiritual experience. Salvation is seen as a reality which keeps on unfolding even in the present time. Christians are referred to as people "being saved" (1Corinthians 1:18; 15:2; Romans 5:10). In Philippians 2:12, we are challenged to continue to "work out (our) salvation" which indicates a present continuous action. The crux of this view of salvation according to Baptists is that all Christians who are already saved by the death of Christ should endeavour to become all that Christ has purposed them to be through His life as they live according to God's design and purpose on a daily basis. This is practically experienced in the process of sanctification as they enjoy victory over the power of sin (temptations). Sanctification is the activity of God which liberates Christians from the power of sin and imparts the righteousness of God through man.

    Sharing Time: What are you doing to work out your salvation with fear and trembling?

  4. Glorification: Salvation as Future

    Another concept in the plan of salvation is our glorification. Baptists view glorification as the zenith of salvation and is the final blessed and abiding state of the redeemed. Salvation is God's act which will be completely and fully enjoyed in the future time. A few of such Scriptures which have led Baptists to hold this belief are: "Salvation is nearer to us now than when we first believed"; "...and He will appear a second time, not to bear sin, but to bring salvation to those who are waiting for Him"; "... are guarded through faith for a salvation ready to be revealed in the last time" (Romans 13:11; 1 Thessalonians 5:9; 2 Timothy 2:10; Hebrews 9:28; Philippians 1:6; Romans 5:9-11; 1 Peter 1:5). From the Scriptures above, this aspect of salvation is described as being nearer than when we first believed (Romans 13:11), that Christ is to bring it and that it is ready to be revealed at His second coming. It is the conviction of Baptists that this aspect of our salvation will be ultimately and practically enjoyed at the glorification at which time the sin the nature will be removed and the believer will be given a perfect body (Philippians 3:20-21).

Facilitator's Closing Remarks

Baptists believe in one salvation, which is revealed to us in three stages: past, present and future. Salvation as can be seen is "the act of God in Christ, rescuing us from the penalty, power and presence of sin for the purpose of justification, sanctification and glorification." Therefore, as sinners, sin separates us from God and condemns us to eternity in hell. But God loves us and sent His only Son, Jesus, to die on the cross to pay the penalty for our sins. Through His death, burial and resurrection He defeated sin and death and made it possible for all who place their trust in Him to have their sins washed away and receive eternal life. All you have to do is repent, turn away from evil, believe in Jesus Christ and put your trust in Him today.

Activity Period

  1. While salvation is freely offered to all who will believe, what is the process whereby we become recipients of God's grace and become Christians?
  2. What do you think will happen if we turn down the gift of salvation?

ROAD MAP FOR DISCIPLES

Jude, in a bid to combat the heretical teachings ravaging the church in the first century of Christianity, felt the need to write and urge his readers "to contend for the faith that was once for all entrusted to the saints". The contemporary, church no doubt, is not immune to similar onslaught from heretical teachings. from centuries till date, many fundamental doctrines of the Gospel have fallen under severe attacks of heretical teachers and these have to be defended. As Christ's disciples, we must be ready to give a logical defense to anyone who asks us to account for our faith and practices (1 Peter 3:21), in line with the Scripture which is the final authority for our faith and practices. To what extent does this describe you: "I am a Baptist member saved by grace through my faith in God in Christ as revealed in the Bible"?

title: more of his character
message:
FEBRUARY WEEK 1

MORE OF HIS CHARACTER

HYMN: BH 216 I Am Resolved

SCRIPTURE: Philippians 2:1-11

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  1. List three characteristics of Jesus.
  2. Differentiate between Jesus' real love and the kind of love people profess on Valentine's Day.

ICE BREAKING PERIOD: Group Discussion

Philippians 2:5 says, `In your relationships with one another, have the same mindset as Christ Jesus.' How can you have the same mindset as Jesus?

Facilitator's Opening Remarks

The Bible declared, `Then God said, let us make man….' (Genesis 1:26) Only man was made in God's image: as a spiritual being, intellectual, relational, and with moral consciousness. When sin damaged God's image in man, God was gracious to man. He sent Jesus to restore that image which man lost. The full image and likeness of God is Jesus Christ (2 Corinthians 4:4; Hebrews 1:3; Colossians 1:15). God's intention is to reproduce His character in man (Ephesians 4:22). Rick Warren said, `God's ultimate goal for your life on earth is not comfort, but character development.' The Fruit of the Spirit is a perfect picture of Christ`s character (Galatians 5:22-23).

EDUCATION/INTERACTION PERIOD

In this teaching and sharing moment, we shall consider the following characters of Jesus:

  1. Love (Philippians 2:1b)

    One attribute of Jesus is love. Jesus declared that God loved the world and sent His Son to die (John 3:16). The implication is that love is God's character, and any disciple who does not love does not know God (1 John 4:7-8). Jesus commands His disciples to love God, and their neighbours because that is the proof of their discipleship (John 13:35). The world thinks of love as a feeling which must be expressed even if moral principles are compromised. Valentine season's display of supposed love is an example of how many misunderstand love. The display of such love at this period is selfish, ungodly and lustful. However, the real love is in Christ, which is holy, just and perfect. Do you display real love in the choices you make and actions you take daily?

    Sharing Time: In your church, do members love one another or every one another?

  2. Humility (Philippians 2:3-5)

    Jesus humbled Himself more than any person in history. Paul, in our text, unveils the humility of Christ that resulted to glory. He also commands us to be humble (v.3). We must understand the humility of Christ for us to be humble. Paul explained Christ's humility in three parts:

    • Jesus did not exploit His divine nature. "He had equal status with God but didn\'t think so much of himself that he had to cling to the advantages of that status no matter what." (Philipians 2:6, THE MESSAGE).
    • Jesus became a man and died on the cross, "...he set aside the privileges of deity and took on the status of a slave, became human!" (Philippians 2:7, THE MESSAGE)
    • Jesus died humiliatingly not ordinarily. "Having become human... he lived a selfless, obedient life and then died a selfless, obedient death and the worst kind of death at that: a crucifixion." (Philippians 2:8 THE MESSAGE).

    Jesus taught His disciples humility when He washed their feet (John 13:1-17). This example is a lesson for us to have a servant's attitude and minister to one another. True humility is described in Philippians 2:1-11. Therefore, humility does not mean demeaning or thinking poorly of ourselves. Humility earns a disciple the favour of elevation before God.

    Sharing Time: In what ways can we show humility?

  3. Tenderness and Compassion (Philippians 2:1b; Colossians 3:12)

    Tenderness and compassion are other things. Jesus modelled to strengthen unity. Selfishness brings disunity and can ruin a church. Like Jesus, believers are to be tender and compassionate. When God appeared to Moses on Mount Sinai, He claimed as part of His title "tenderness" and "compassion". Tenderness has been defined as a tendency to express warm and affectionate feelings towards someone, soft heartedness that is concerned with the welfare of others. God said through Isaiah portraying His tenderness and compassion, "Can a mother forget the baby at her breast and have no compassion… I will not forget you" (Isaiah 49:15). Compassion was evoked in Jesus Himself, sometimes to the point of tears when He came face to face with pain, sorrow, hunger, loneliness and bewilderment in others (Matthew 9:36). He witnessed the grief of Lazarus' sisters. He wept with them (John 11:35). He showed compassion to the widow of Nain (Luke 7:13). Like Jesus, each disciple's intentional compassionate action contributes to the growth of spiritual transformation.

    Sharing Time: Two members should explain moments of tenderness and compassion they have experienced or witnessed.

Facilitator's Closing Remarks

Christlike character is what we need to demonstrate to bring about changes in our family, church, society, nation, and the entire world. The Christian love is the primary mode of transformation. Christ loves us and we must love Him back. We must humble ourselves and give up the hidden pride in us. Love, humility, compassion and tenderness are possible if we have the mind of Christ.

Activity Period

  1. Pray to God for humility. Ask Him to forgive you for your pride.
  2. Do one act of tenderness and compassion after this lesson.
  3. How will you correct lustful love at Valentine with Christ's real love?

title: more of his teaching
message:
FEBRUARY WEEK 2

MORE OF HIS TEACHING

HYMN: BH 321 More About Jesus

SCRIPTURE: Matthew 5:13-16, 21- 22; 27-30; 6:25-34

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  1. List three things Jesus taught.
  2. Explain why Jesus' teaching was different and difficult for people to accept.

ICE BREAKING PERIOD: Group Discussion

In the `Sermon on the Mount,' one of the teachings of Jesus is to love our enemies and pray for those who persecute us so that we may be like our heavenly Father (Matthew 5:44-45). Two members should share with the group how they have obeyed this teaching.

Facilitator's Opening Remarks

Last week, we considered the character of Jesus where He taught by His lifestyle. Today, we are learning more about Jesus' teachings from His Sermon on the Mount. Generally, Christ's teachings can be found in the books of Matthew, Mark, Luke and John. However, today's lesson is taken from the Sermon on the Mount (Matthew 5-7). Jesus taught in Matthew 5:43-48 that we should love our enemies. Jesus' authority in teaching when contrasted with that of the scribes is emphatic and explicit. His teachings called the hearers to make decision and commitment. We are to obey His teachings and make commitments.

EDUCATION/INTERACTION PERIOD

  1. Salt and Light (Matthew 5:13-16)

    Jesus said, "You are...," not "you should or you may". This is a call to a new understanding of oneself. Salt and light model a disciple's true identity as opposed to decay and darkness. Since salt and light derive their functions from their nature, being has priority over saying and doing. It follows that what a person is will be expressed in what the person says or does. Jesus addresses the issue of identity here. Who are you? What Jesus says about your personality is more important than your view of low self-image. Jesus says disciples are the salt of the earth, the light of the world and a city set upon a hill. The symbols of salt and light assure people of their worth and call them to their mission. The point is that being determines function. While salt preserves and seasons; light shines and exposes. It is expected of Christ's disciples to influence the society by shining as light to a world that is morally decaying. God designed the church to consist of people who are "called out" from the world. We are to live consecrated lives.

    Sharing Time: How would someone with injury on his leg react if salt is put on it? How does this describe Christians' relationship to the world?

  2. Adultery (Matthew 5:27-30)

    Adultery is the sin of a married man having sexual relations with anyone other than his wife or vice-versa. Adultery is a sin which begins deep within us in terms of feeling, impulse and intention. The problem of lust in human hearts leads to various sexual sins. It is obvious that Jesus is explaining not just the letter of the law on adultery but also the spirit of the law, the law's intent. It is not enough to avoid certain external sinful behaviours. We also need to honour God with our thoughts, our motives and our attitudes. Jesus' teaching does not say that sexuality is evil; its concern is in what is done with sexual desire. Sex should be brought under control. No person is to be reduced to just a sex object. Sex is a beautiful gift God gives to married couples. The church must create space for healthy discussions about sex. Whenever an adult is involved in extramarital affair with someone who is not his/her spouse, it is adultery and it is a sin.

    Sharing Time: How will you share the Gospel with an adulterer?

  3. Worry (Matthew 6:25-34)

    God wants us to trust Him and to have faith in Him always. Jesus said, "If God cares so wonderfully for wild flowers …He will certainly care for you" (Matthew 6:30). We have to put God first in our lives and allow Him to fill our thoughts with His desires, take His character for our pattern and serve and obey Him in everything. Today, many people have replaced the position of God with people, objects, goals and other desires. Jesus said, "... do not worry about tomorrow... (Matthew 6:34). Beloved, while planning for tomorrow is a time well spent, worrying about tomorrow is a time wasted. Careful planning is thinking ahead about goals, steps and schedules, and trusting in God's guidance. Planning can help alleviate worry. Worry by contrast steals our peace, physically wears us out, and can even make us sick. It makes us find it difficult to trust God. Therefore, we should not allow worries about tomorrow affect our relationship with God today. Remember, yesterday is a cancelled cheque, tomorrow is a promissory note, and today is all you've got. Rather than worry about things you can't change, it is better you pour all your worries upon Jesus because He cares for you.

    Sharing Time: Members should discuss the causes of worry?

Facilitator's Closing Remarks

The teachings of Jesus are central to different aspects of relationship. Jesus taught the lessons He was looking for in His followers. If we desire to be like Him, we must allow these teachings to challenge the way we live every day. We must do His will at all times and bless those who disagree with us.

Activity Period

  1. Allow members to mention the teachings of Jesus they are guilty of and explain what they will do after this lesson.
  2. Allow members to pray and ask God to release upon them His working and enabling grace.

title: more of his power
message:
FEBRUARY WEEK 3

MORE OF HIS POWER

HYMN: BH 193 There Is Power in the Blood

SCRIPTURE: 2 Corinthians 12:1-10; 1 Corinthians 4:20; Ephesians 3:20

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  1. Understand Jesus' power.
  2. Ascertain if they have God's power in their lives.
  3. Mention ways a believer can have the power of God.

ICE BREAKING PERIOD: Brainstorming

Members are to read this quotation and discuss the question together; "He could not do any miracles there, except lay his hands on a few people who were ill and healed them. He was amazed at their lack of faith" (Mark 6:5, 6). Can we say that Christ's power to perform miracles is predicated upon the faith of those He taught?

Facilitator's Opening Remarks

We have considered some of Christ's character and teachings in the last two weeks. Today, we are considering His power. Dictionaries define the word `Power' in a number of ways but our focus is power as ability to act or produce an effect. Jesus told His disciples that they would receive power when the Holy Spirit comes on them (Acts 1:8). The power to be a witness of the Gospel was important after their training in order to continue with the Great Commission. It is more of God's power in the life of a believer that is needed to fulfil His divine purpose. A believer will live a fulfilled life if he lives by God's power. Jesus declared to His disciples that all power in heaven and on earth has been given to Him (Matthew 28:19, KJV). Let us examine some acts of God\'s power.

EDUCATION/INTERACTION PERIOD

  1. Understanding Jesus' Power

    Power is the control that some people search for in life. Some talk about the power a personality commands. Others talk about the power of various objects or systems in this world. Few talk about the power of God. The life of Jesus was characterised by supernatural power with which He was endued from above. He said, "All power in heaven and on earth is given to me" (Matthew 28:18 NCV). The Scripture shows that Jesus had power in Him; that when He healed, power went out from Him. The power that surrounded Jesus was supernatural, not normal physical or natural power. Let us think about this power for a short moment. This power was given to Jesus not for Him to use it for Himself. You will remember that He refused to turn stones into bread, that He would not use power for public acclamation, etc. It was to enable Jesus to do God's will. The power did not die with Jesus. He said after His resurrection that the power is available for His disciples to be His witnesses in Jerusalem, and in all Judea and Samaria, and to the ends of the earth (Acts 1:8 NIV). And like Jesus, divine power was used to equip the disciples to do God's will. They trusted in Jesus' power to expand God's kingdom. Indeed the apostles endured hardship, troubles and deaths by the divine power. It is power that is at its strongest when we are weak in ourselves and rely on Him.

    Sharing Time: Let a member share how God's power encouraged him/her during persecution or hardship.

  2. What Jesus' Power Conveys to the Disciples
    1. Jesus' power is made perfect in weakness (2 Corinthians 12: 9-10)

      In response to Paul's prayer, Jesus said, "My grace is sufficient for you, for my power is made perfect in weakness…" (vv. 9-10). Four words in verse 10 help us to understand the kind of weakness Paul was referring to in this passage: insults, hardships, persecutions and difficulties. Weakness here is not a sin but circumstances, situations, experiences and wounds that makes us weak and weary.

    2. Jesus' power over death (John 10:17-18)

      Jesus is powerful. He raised the following people from death: Jairus' daughter (Mark 5:35-43), the son of the widow of Nain (Luke 7: 14-15), Lazarus the brother of Mary and Martha (John 11:43-44). He finally laid down His life and took it up again with His own power. He rose from the grave to eternal life, just like believers will receive life over death through the power of Jesus.

    3. Jesus' power over sin (Matthew 9:6; Luke 5:24)

      There is no one who can forgive sin except God. Jesus forgives sins because He has power to do so. Jesus has power to heal sicknesses, cast out unclean spirits, execute judgment, etc. He is the head of all principalities and powers. He gave power to His disciples against unclean spirits (Luke 9:1-2). Jesus will come again with power (Matthew 24:30; Mark 13:26). Jesus gives His disciples power to become sons of God (John 1:12-13). The power of Jesus which is a gift to all believers is limitless. The power of God is calling you today to salvation, believe in Jesus' saving power, be cleansed from all your sins, be forgiven and receive eternal life.

    Sharing Time: Members should differentiate between man's power and Jesus' power.

  3. Getting God's Power

    There are different kinds of power but Christ's power is greater than all of them. Paul said, "For the kingdom of God is not a matter of talk but of power" (1 Corinthians 4:20). God's power is able to do more than believers can imagine (Ephesians 3:20). But the pertinent question is how believers get God's power. Rick Warren in his message, `Get God's Power,' presented three ways a believer can get the power of God namely: by praying, because prayer and power go together; by taking risks to obey God even when it doesn't make sense to anybody, because God will pour His power on any one that takes risks to obey him. Abraham, Noah and Paul were examples. Lastly, believers must persist and should not give up until they get the power.

    Sharing Time: Members should mention other ways believers can get the power of Jesus.

Facilitator's Closing Remarks

Do we rely on our own power for God's work or on His Power? Do we rely on the power of God to change and transform us and to enable us to be used by God? The productivity is not ours but God's. We must absolutely rely on His power and daily ask for more of His power from above. Disciples of Jesus need more of His power in their lives. We are to depend on the Holy Spirit to get the power to pray, to take risks to obey God and refuse to give up. His power does not fail and is available to those who have received Jesus as Saviour and Lord.

Activity Period

  1. Allow one of the members to explain an occasion when he/she experienced the manifestation of the power of Jesus.
  2. Ask a member to explain God's response to Paul in 2 Corinthians 12:9, "My grace is sufficient for you, for my power is made perfect in weakness."

title: more of his saving grace
message:
FEBRUARY WEEK 4

More of His Saving Grace

HYMN: BH 188 Amazing Grace

SCRIPTURE: Ephesians 2: 8-9; Titus 2:11

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  1. Differentiate between grace and saving grace.
  2. Mention at least four lessons that Jesus' saving grace teaches.

ICE BREAKING PERIOD: Group Discussion

Oghenero was very sick and she was admitted in the hospital. She needed blood transfusion but the available blood type could not be used for her. It was the seventeen years' old Eze's blood that was acceptable. The doctor told him to donate blood for his dying sister. When Eze saw the doctor after blood transfusion, he asked; `When will I die?' The doctor told him that donating blood will not lead to his death. How does this story resemble Christ's saving grace to the world?

Facilitator's Opening Remarks

We have considered Jesus' character, teachings and power. Our final discussion is on Jesus' saving grace. Saving grace refers to God's grace to lead a person to salvation. This assertion is based on a variety of biblical principles that emphasise salvation as free gift of God's grace rather than something that a person earns through good deeds and actions. No level of human accomplishments is good enough to obtain salvation. The only way to receive God's saving grace is through faith in Christ (Isaiah 64:6; Ephesians2: 8-9).

EDUCATION/INTERACTION PERIOD

  1. Sister Ngozi Erekosima: What Is Grace? What Is Christ's Saving Grace? (Ephesians 2:8-9)

    Someone said grace means, `unmerited divine assistance given to humans for their regeneration or sanctification'. Grace is Christ's unmerited favour, an undeserved goodness. Christ's saving grace is the grace of God that saves a person from sin and guilt. Jesus Christ Himself is our saving grace. The only way believers were declared righteous was by the provision of salvation for them through grace apart from works. Jesus' death on the cross is what saves us, not our own merit (Ephesians 2:9). No one receives a gift from someone and asks how much he should pay because it is a gift. The simple response to a gift is `thank you'. In the same way, the Christians' response to the saving grace of God that brought salvation should be gratitude, praise and joy because (a) Christ's saving grace extends to all men (Titus 2:11; 1 Timothy 2:4; 2 Peter 3:9; Ezekiel 33:11); (b) Christ's saving grace extends even to those who reject it and ultimately perish (Matthew 23:37; 2 Peter 2:1). From these passages and others, Jesus' saving grace is serious and efficacious.

    Sharing Time: Let members demonstrate how they will explain Jesus' saving grace to their neighbours who are not Christians.

  2. Deaconess Miriam Ayuba: The Saving Grace Versus Cheap Grace

    There are some people who advocate a form of grace that is called "cheap grace" that is different from saving grace. Cheap grace argues that grace alone is responsible for everything and so a person does not have to change. They can continue to live in sin and they will not face any consequences. To proponents of cheap grace, the sins are justified but the person is not and so continues to live in sin. They view God's love and forgiveness of sins as a general truth and not as life transforming agents. Saving grace (which is biblical) proponents agree that grace alone, Christ alone, and faith alone are sufficient (Ephesians 2:8-9). Saving grace requires a change in lifestyle.

  3. Deacon Ore-Ofe Oluwatomigba: The Seven Lessons of the Saving Grace (Titus 2: 11-13)

    Jesus' saving grace teaches the following lessons according to Dake's Annotated Reference Bible:

    1. To deny ungodliness (v. 12)
    2. To deny worldly lusts (v. 12)
    3. To live soberly (v. 12; 1:8; 2:2-7)
    4. To live righteously (v. 12; Hebrews 12:14; Romans 6:14-23; 8:12-13)
    5. To live godly (v. 12; 2 Timothy 3:12)
    6. To live right in this life (v 12)
    7. To look for the rapture and the Second Advent (v. 13; Philippians 3:20).

    Sharing Time: Members should mention and discuss worldly lusts they must deny.

  4. Dr Mrs Favour: The Results of Saving Grace (Titus 2:11-14)

    One of the results of saving grace is sanctification. Wayne Grudem said, `Sanctification is a progressive work of God and man that makes us more and more free from sin and be like Christ in our actual lives'. Another result of Christ's saving grace is that it removes the Christian from future punishment in eternity and separation from God. It is a great blessing for condemned sinners to be saved and be with Jesus in paradise. This reminds us of three great benefits from the Life Application Study Bible that believers anticipate when Christ returns: Christ personal presence (believers look forward to being with Him), redemption from sinful desire (Christians long for the end of the battle with sin and believers' perfection in Christ), restoration of creation (Christians anticipate the complete rule of grace when the image of God will be fully realised in people and when the created order will be restored).

    Sharing Time: Let members explain what sanctification means to them.

Facilitator's Closing Remarks

Christ saving grace saves. It is God's mercy shown to believers. Everyone who is permitted to enter heaven will be there by grace. The teachings of Irvin Himme (Truth Magazine, December1973) on the grace of God, reminds Christians that Jesus' saving grace does not: i. circumvent Jesus Christ, ii. ignore the gospel, iii. permit access apart by faith, iv. rule against baptism for the remission of sins, v. give licence to sin, vi. offer unconditional security, and, vii. does not save on the basis of human merit. God's indwelling grace is active. It leads you and influences you. It brings change to you and within you. The grace that results in salvation should continue to have a profound effect upon our hearts.

Activity Period

  1. Let members read the first stanza of the hymn, `Amazing Grace', and explain what it means to them.
  2. Members should differentiate between cheap grace and the saving grace.
  3. Mention at least four lessons that Jesus' saving grace teaches.

ROAD MAP FOR DISCIPLES

Every disciple should desire to know more about Jesus through relationship. Relationship with Jesus helps believers to know Him better, to love and obey Him. No disciple should ever be satisfied with his level of knowing Jesus. Christlike discipleship is a lifelong relationship of knowing more of Jesus. When last did you do self examination of your relationship with Christ? Do you study the Bible every day? Do you pray always in the name of Jesus? What about your time alone with God? What about your church prayer fellowship and discipleship training course? When you have relationship with Jesus' you will desire fellowship with Him always. You know Jesus more and more as you have constant fellowship with Him.

As disciples of Jesus Christ, we have considered four lessons relating to knowing more about Jesus' character, teachings, power and saving grace. Christlike character is the ultimate goal of all Christian education. Do people see the character of Jesus __ love, humility, tenderness and compassion __ in your life? Christ teachings personally touch life, culture, traditions and societies. Jesus in His teachings demands obedience and commitment from His hearers. Are you committed to obeying Jesus' teachings? A believer will live a fulfilled life if he lives by the power of Jesus. Are you on track? Are you praying to get more of Jesus' power, ready to take risks to obey God even when it doesn't make sense to you? Have you been saved by His grace? Don't forget these teachings as Christ's disciples. Obey them as to make a difference for Christ in this generation.

title: simon of cyrene and joseph of arimathea
message:
MARCH WEEK 1

SIMON OF CYRENE AND JOSEPH OF ARIMATHEA

HYMN: BH 99 When I Survey the Wondrous Cross

SCRIPTURE: Matthew 27:32; Luke 23:50-56

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  1. Examine the role Simon of Cyrene and Joseph of Arimathea played in the Easter narratives.
  2. Apply same in their daily walk with God.

ICE BREAKING PERIOD: Opinion Sharing

Let one member of the class share how he/she felt after rendering assistance to the needy.

Facilitator\'s Opening Remarks

It is a good habit to render help to someone who is in need. However, it is not always possible to help someone especially when such an individual is responsible for his troubles. Ideally, rendering help is at its best when it is done willingly, without coercion. Our lesson today reveals two men in the Easter narratives who rendered assistance to Jesus. One of them, Simon of Cyrene, was forced by soldiers to carry the cross of Jesus. The cross was a negative social symbol, an emblem of suffering and shame. Someone carrying a cross is not likely to get assistance or attract sympathy, but is solely an individual responsibility. The other, Joseph of Arimathea, offered his tomb voluntarily for the body of Jesus to be buried. In seeking the good of others, Joseph gave his tomb, his convenience, and risks his class or status in exchange for shame.

EDUCATION/INTERACTION PERIOD

  1. Simon's Identity and Personality Matthew 27:32
    1. Simon is a Greek personal name which means, "flat-nosed." It is used in the New Testament as Greek alternative of the Hebrew word for "Simeon."
    2. He was from Cyrene, a city located in northern Africa where modern Libya is now located (Hale, 281). It was the capital city of the Roman district of Cyrenaica during the New Testament era.
    3. He may have belonged to the rather large population of the Greek-speaking Jews who resided in the city during the first century A.D.
    4. Simon of Cyrene was a responsible family man and Mark identifies him as the father of Alexander and Rufus.

    Sharing Time: Why was Simon the Cyrene compelled to carry Jesus\' cross?

  2. Simon's Role in the Easter Narrative

    Simon\'s main role was that he lent a helping hand to Jesus, though forced. The compelling nature of this service is buttressed in the synoptic accounts. Matthew and Mark in their narratives use the verb "forced "or "compelled" while Luke, on the other hand uses the verb "seized." By implication, the soldiers forced, compelled, or seized Simon to help carry the cross that brought salvation to the human race. Considering the weight of the cross and torture Jesus went through in their hands and being afraid that Jesus may likely die on the way before reaching the place of His execution, they forced Simon to lend a helping hand to Jesus by carrying His cross. Simon of Cyrene actually did for Jesus what one of His disciples should have done for Him at that hour, if they had not deserted Him when arrested. God brought this man from Africa to render help to Jesus in the hour of His greatest need.

    Sharing Time: What will God do if we fail to render assistance to someone who needs it?

  3. Joseph's Identity and Personality Luke 23:50-56
    1. Joseph was a wealthy Jew who came from Arimathea in Judea (Luke 23:51).
    2. He was a good and righteous man and a member of the Council (the Sanhedrin).
    3. He was a biblical figure who played an important role in the burial of Jesus Christ. His account can be found in each of the four Gospels: Matthew 27:57-60; Mark 15:42-46; Luke 23:50-53 and John 19:38-42.
    4. He asked Pilate for permission to take Jesus\' body for burial after the crucifixion in his private "burial ground". Permission was granted and the body was taken down.
    5. He was a "secret disciple" of Jesus which was why he did not join in the Council\'s actions against Jesus.

    Sharing Time: Discuss who is a worthy disciple: whether in secret or public? A worthy disciple that honours and respects his master\'s will is always at his duty post. This is what other public disciples could not do.

  4. Joseph's Role in the Easter Narratives
    1. Joseph requested to bury the body of Jesus (Mark 15:42-43). Note: Where were the other disciples? Among the disciples only John is recorded as being present at the foot of the cross (John 19:26).
    2. Usually, the Romans do not allow crucified criminals to have decent burial; they left their bodies hanging on the cross for the birds to eat. They do this as a deterrent to others. But according to Jewish law, it was necessary to bury the body of a person on the day he died (Deuteronomy 21:22-23). This is the reason Joseph asked Pilate for permission to bury Jesus\' body.
  5. The Implications for Believers
    1. AVAILIBILITY: Both men made themselves available for the service of the Lord. We are also challenged to lay down our lives for others. Jesus laid down His life for others; we are also called to die to self, pride and selfish ambition. Let each man seek the good of others first. Joseph gave up his tomb, his convenience, his class and he identified with shame instead of honour. God can place us where we will be available for Him to use, to be of help to someone who is in need. Simon became available by carrying the cross of Jesus. How available are you in the hands of God to meet that felt need in the life of that fellow around you?
    2. SERVICE: Jesus did not resist Simon of Cyrene from helping Him to carry the heavy cross. It shows that Jesus must have looked forward to such help because He was exhausted. Inwardly, Jesus must have appreciated the fine gesture of Simon of Cyrene for helping Him to carry the cross to Golgotha. God needs true service like the one by Simon of Cyrene. When we share the burdens of others and the world around us and carry them to God in prayers, it is like "helping" Jesus to carry His cross. God appreciates those whose heartbeat is for the salvation of the lost souls in the world.
    3. LOVE: Love is the compelling force for service. Simon and Joseph loved Jesus. They must have felt pity for Jesus because of the suffering and torture he bore for the sins of humanity. Their spirits and souls must have compelled them to show such concern for their Saviour because they loved Him. If you are a child of God, you should and must allow the love of God to compel you to do that which would have been naturally impossible to do (2 Corinthians 5:14). It is possible that where you are now, God keeps you there for His divine purpose. Simon and Joseph served the purpose of God in Jesus\' life; what about you?
    4. GENEROSITY: Generosity in giving is often a response to gratitude in receiving. Joseph of Arimathea generously donated his own prepared private tomb for the burial of Jesus after Jesus\' crucifixion.

Facilitator's Closing Remarks

Simon and Joseph\'s lives and roles in the Easter storychallenge us to always be sensitive to God\'s leading. We should render help to those who are in need through our selfless services, making ourselves ready for the Master\'s use in this end time. God is ready to use us if we make ourselves available. The above demand is naturally not an easy one but if we allow God\'s love to rule and propel us, it then becomes possible.

Activity Period

  1. How could we make ourselves available for God\'s service this week?
  2. Identify someone who is in need of your love and express same to him/her.

title: the two criminals crucified with jesus
message:
MARCH WEEK 2

THE TWO CRIMINALS CRUCIFIED WITH JESUS

HYMN: BH 96 At Calvary

SCRIPTURE: Luke 23:38-43

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  1. Distinguish between the relationships of each of the robbers at the cross with Jesus.
  2. Assess their own response to the cross.

ICE BREAKING PERIOD: Opinion Sharing

Class members should share some biblical predictions in the Old Testament that have been fulfilled in the New Testament.

Facilitator's Opening Remarks

Many of the predictions made in the Old Testament have been fulfilled in the New Testament though, some are yet to be fulfilled. The prophecy in Isaiah 54:12 which says, "Therefore, I will divide him a portion among the great, and he will divide the spoils with the strong, because he poured out his life unto death, and was numbered with transgressors. For he bore the sin of many and made intercession for the transgressors" was fulfilled in the story of our Lord Jesus\' crucifixion on the cross at Calvary. The prophecy gives the background to the understanding of our lesson today. Isaiah\'s prediction on Christ\'s humiliation and exaltation is fulfilled in Jesus\' crucifixion especially his identification with the criminals. These men had contact with Jesus, played vital roles and become part of the Easter story. Their contributions authenticate biblical prophecy.

EDUCATION/INTERACTION PERIOD

  1. Jesus' Identification with the Criminals

    Robbers are inimical to any family and society. They constitute social threat to human life and property and create security challenge to the government. No normal person in any society will like to be related to robbers because they bring reproach to the family and the community. Yet, it was amidst these criminals that Jesus found Himself at the cross. For our sins, He was numbered among them. Furthermore, the presence of the robbers that were crucified alongside Jesus symbolises His identification with humans. Jesus bore the reproach that was due to man. The implication here is that Christ suffered the shame that was due to us. Jesus suffered with vilest malefactors as if He had been a partaker with them in their sins. He was numbered among the transgressors at His death, that we at our death might be numbered among the living in Christ. He is our life. He came to give us life in abundance. Also, Jesus was crucified in between these notorious criminals, as if he had been the worst of the three, the principal malefactor, for the middle was considered the place for the chief of them all.

  2. The Responses of the Criminals to Jesus

    Luke\'s Gospel says that one of the criminals, "who hung there hurled insults at him. Are you not the Messiah? Save yourself and us." This shows how wicked a sinful man\'s heart can be. The hour of death is not a time to create more trouble for oneself but a time of sober reflection and reconciliation with God and man. This could be the reason the other criminal in response, rebuked his partner in crime on the basis that the hour of death is hardly the appropriate moment for an evildoer like him to insult an innocent man like Jesus. The negative response of the wicked criminal to Jesus at the cross resulted to his physical and spiritual judgment and damnation. On the contrary, the remorseful robber realised that he was a sinner and appealed to Jesus for mercy. He pleaded with Jesus not to forget him when He entered His kingdom. No truly penitent sinner will be in Jesus\' presence without encountering the holiness of God and the grace that can transform his life. Jesus granted the criminal\'s request. He told the repentant thief, "Today you will be with me in paradise." What a joy! The thief only suffered Romans\' judgment for over his crime but through the Saviour, he passed from death unto life eternal.

  3. Implications of Jesus' Identification with the Criminals
    1. Jesus came to save the vilest sinner; He gave His life on the cross for one of the robbers. Though both were on the wooden cross at the same spot, on the same day and watched by the same people, Jesus\' cross and death was significantly different. He came to give His life as a ransom for many.
    2. Jesus does not mind where or how He meets us, His mission is to salvage us from our sin and bring everyone He saves to God. It does not matter the height or the depth of sin committed. There is abundance of grace for the penitent heart. The penitent robber made his decision and confession publicly, you can do the same.
    3. Jesus\' response to this remorseful thief shows that human souls are more valuable to God than anything in the world in that under such terrible condition, Jesus could still minister to that criminal. This is love beyond human understanding.
    4. The power of Jesus\' love and compassion is greater and stronger than the power of sin in our lives. It is sure evidence that sin cannot totally separate us from the love of Christ if we repent and do not continue in unbelief and rebellion which will bring eternal damnation to our souls.
    5. The other thief was wicked to his spirit, soul and body. Thus he received man\'s judgment and death as well as God\'s judgment that leads to the damnation of his soul in hell.

Facilitator's Closing Remarks

What is your response to Jesus, especially during this Easter period? Jesus is ready to identify with you at this period of remembering His suffering, death and resurrection from the dead. However, the big issue is our willingness to respond appropriately to His will and plan for our lives. To the unsaved whose heart is far from God, like the second robber, change your mind by turning towards Christ before it is too late.

Activity Period

  1. Assess your response to Jesus and the cross at this season.
  2. Preach the message of the cross to a sinner.

title: mary, the mother of jesus and the other mary
message:
MARCH WEEK 3

MARY, THE MOTHER OF JESUS AND THE OTHER MARY

HYMN: BH 97 Jesus, Keep Me Near the Cross

SCRIPTURE: Matthew 28:1-10

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  1. Describe the roles played by Mary, the mother of Jesus and the other Mary in Easter narratives.
  2. Apply same in their daily walk with God.

ICE BREAKING PERIOD: Opinion Sharing

Should Mary the mother of Jesus Christ be worshipped or honoured?

Facilitator's Opening Remarks

Some Christian groups worship Mary and even pray to God through her. Their reason for the worship is based on the role that Mary played in history, especially during the birth of Christ. God was in her womb. In conceiving and bearing the Lord Jesus Christ, she gave birth not to mere man but to the Son of God Himself. In respect to this they claim, Mary deserves to be worshipped. Furthermore, this same group claims that Mary remained a virgin after the birth of Christ and that Jesus\' brothers and sisters mentioned in Matthew 13:55-56; Mark 6:3 were either Joseph\'s children by an earlier marriage or were cousins of Jesus. On the other hand, some other Christian groups argue that Mary is not an object of worship and even neglect her and her contributions in the Easter narrative. Inasmuch as the Bible does not teach or present Mary as an object of worship, it does present her as a woman of high character and faith. Consequently, Mary should be accorded the respect and recognition due to her among Christians. Our lesson this week focuses on the roles that Mary the mother of Jesus and the other Mary played in the Easter story. What can be said of them that are consistent with the Holy Scripture? Moreover, what character traits can be emulated from them that could spur us to be more committed to God and His service on earth?

EDUCATION/INTERACTION PERIOD

  1. Mary, the Mother of Jesus

    We do not have much information about the background of Mary, the mother of Jesus. However, Luke introduced Mary, in his gospel as a woman of high character and faith (Luke 1:26-38). She probably resided in Nazareth a town in Galilee where she received an angelic visitation. Mary was a virgin pledged to be married to a man named Joseph, a descendant of David (Luke 1:26-27). Out of God\'s grace, Mary became the mother of Jesus Christ on earth. (Luke 1:26-38). The text only mentioned one relative of Mary called Elizabeth, the wife of Zechariah (Luke1:39) who resided in Hebron. The latter was also favoured with God\'s blessing of the womb after so many years of barrenness (Luke 1:36-37). At crucifixion, where Christ, almost with His last words, commends His mother the care of the disciple whom He loved, Mary was taken into his home (John 19:25-27).

    Sharing Time: What is the role of character in the practice of faith?

  2. Her Character
    1. A woman of high moral standard. The Bible records that Mary was a virgin (Luke1:27). She still kept her virginity even after her betrothal to Joseph (Matthew 1:18).
    2. A woman of faith, patience and humility. Her faith and humility exhibit themselves in the immediate surrender of herself to the divine will though ignorant of how that was to be accomplished (Luke 1:38).
    3. A strong woman. She exhibited energy and earnestness in her journey from Nazareth to Hebron (hill country of Judea) v. 38.
    4. A woman of meditation. This trait is seen in Mary\'s thoughtfulness in pondering over the shepherds\' visit (2:19) and, in keeping her son\'s words in her heart (v. 51), though she could not fully understand their importance.

    Sharing Time: Discuss other traits of Mary, the mother of Jesus which have not been mentioned.

  3. The Other Mary

    The phrase "the other Mary" refers to Mary Magdalene who with other women ministered to Jesus and His disciples "out of their means" (Luke 8:2-3). She was said to have been possessed by seven demons (v. 2). This ministration brought Mary Magdalene, Salome and Mary, the mother of James and John into companionship (Mark 15:40), and also with Mary the mother of the Lord (John 19:25), "stood at a distance, watching these things" (Luke 23:41), during the closing hours of Christ\'s agony on the cross.

    Sharing Time: What noteworthy service have you done for the Lord?

  4. The Women's Roles at Easter Narratives and their Implications
    1. Discipleship. The women were disciples of Christ who not only followed Jesus by placing their faith in Him, but have physically and faithfully followed Jesus from Galilee to Jerusalem where He was crucified and buried (Luke 23:55; Matthew 27:61; Mark 15:47). They remained by the cross till Jesus\' death and they waited till the body was buried in the tomb of Joseph of Arimathea (Luke 23:55). Christians are also called to be disciples of Christ in faith and practice (Luke 9:23). In other to do this, we must give up self interest and disobedience (Romans 6:17).
    2. Service. They did not only follow Jesus, they cared for Him (Mark 15:40-41). Even at death, they cared for Jesus (Mark 16:1; Matthew 28:1. 5; Mark 16:2, 5). Christians should therefore use whatever is at their disposal to serve the Lord and humanity. Such kind of service goes a long way in meeting people\'s needs.
    3. Empathy. Mary Magdalene with other women went to the tomb to anoint the body of Jesus (Mark 16:1-5) and ran to Peter and John to inform them that the stone had been rolled away from the mouth of the tomb of Jesus (Luke 24:10; John 20:1-2). Likewise, Christians are to empathise with the poor, marginalised, persecuted and oppressed people of the world.
    4. Evangelism. When they met the resurrected Lord, the women spread the news abroad (Matthew 28:8). Easter is a time of proclamation of Christ\'s love and sacrifice to humankind. Let us go to set the captives free and raise-up the dead (Matthew 28:19-20; Acts 1:8).

    Sharing Time: What other roles do these women perform at Easter?

Facilitator's Closing Remarks

From the two characters, we have studied thus far; we discovered that, living a godly life attracts God\'s blessings. Mary said "... From now on all generations will call me blessed" (Luke 1:48). Their roles in the Easter narratives pose challenges to us. Let us therefore make ourselves available in this season so that the Lord will make us vessels of honour in our time and generation.

Activity Period

  1. Mention some practical roles you can play during this Easter season.
  2. Go for hospital evangelism or prison ministry at this period.

title: the disciple whom jesus loved
message:
MARCH WEEK 4

THE DISCIPLE WHOM JESUS LOVED

HYMN: BH 399 I Gave My Life for Thee

SCRIPTURE: John 19:25-27

Objectives :

By the end of the class the members should be able to describe the responsibilities Christ\'s love demands from them.

ICE BREAKING PERIOD: Opinion Sharing

Discuss this statement, "Every privilege comes with corresponding responsibility."

Facilitator's Opening Remarks

Indeed, every privilege comes with corresponding responsibility. It is a favour to be called a child of God. This identity with Christ is predicated on Christ\'s love. He is the lover of our souls. He did not only love us but He suffered and died for us. He sacrificed His life on the cross of Calvary so as to redeem us from the bondage of sin and death. He who knew no sin became sin so that we might become the righteous ones of God. He offered His body as a ransom for all who exercise faith in Him as their Saviour. He shed His blood in order to cleanse us from all contaminations. He protects us even when we experience the storms of life. However, Christ\'s love demands responsibility. He wants us to demonstrate or reciprocate that love to Him and to others. Our lesson this week focuses on the disciple Jesus loved and how Jesus demanded from him to reciprocate same to His mother. How will you reciprocate Christ\'s love to you in this season?

EDUCATION/INTERACTION PERIOD

  1. The Personality of the Beloved Disciple

    The statement "the disciple whom Jesus loved" is mentioned three times in John\'s gospel (13:23; 19:26; 20:2). The first mention was when Jesus predicted His betrayal in John 13:23. He was described as one that was reclining next to Jesus. He enjoyed the closest relationship with Jesus; therefore Peter told John to ask Jesus which of the disciples would be the betrayer. The second mention was at the cross, when Jesus was about dying (19:26). At this juncture, Jesus saddled John with a responsibility of caring for His mother. The third mention was in John 20:2, where Mary Magdalene ran to Peter and this disciple and informed them of the empty tomb. Who is this disciple that Jesus loved? It is true that the name of this disciple is not mentioned. Nevertheless, it is generally agreed that this disciple whom Jesus loved is John, the apostle, who wrote the Gospel according to John. And this John was the son of Zebedee.

    Sharing Time: Discuss why the disciple chose the designation "the disciple whom Jesus loved" instead of his real name, John.

  2. The Privilege: Christ's Love

    John enjoyed the love of Christ during Jesus\' earthly ministry. This love is seen in diverse ways:

    1. He was called to become a disciple (Luke 6:12-16).
    2. He had a special place he stayed when the disciples assembled for supper (John 13:23).
    3. He was among the inner circle of Jesus (Matthew 26:37).
    4. He witnessed the transfiguration of Jesus, (Matthew 17:1-3).
    5. He outlived other disciples on earth (John 21:22-23).
    6. He received the revelation of Jesus Christ (Revelation 1:1).

      7. In summary, Jesus and John were essentially "best of friends". That is a wonderful privilege that demands responsibility.

    Sharing Time: Mention and share your privileges in Christ with the members.

  3. The Responsibility of "the disciple whom Jesus loved" John 19:26

    Even as Jesus was dying, He thought of His mother who was standing there with John. He said, `Dear woman, here is your son\'. By implication, John was to be like a biological son of Mary and was to care for her. From this we can surmise that Jesus\' father, Joseph had probably died; otherwise he would have been the one responsible for his wife. Again, Jesus did not place this responsibility on His brothers (John 7:5; Acts 1:14) rather, He requested John to care for His mother. From that day on, John took responsibility for her, as if he were her own son.

    Sharing Time: Why did Jesus not place the care of His mother on His brothers? (Read John 7:5 and Acts 1:14).

  4. Implications of Being Loved by Jesus

    How can you reciprocate your love for Jesus during this Easter period? What service can you render to Christ or to other people in appreciation to Christ who first loved you? Jesus wants you to be His representative wherever you are and go (2 Corinthians 5:20a). The woman or man in your neighbourhood who needs love and care wants your visit and love. The widow in your church that is old and helpless needs your care right now. The sick and bedridden need your prayers. Both physical and spiritual prisoners need your attention this season. The handicapped, the oppressed of the society and those under societal stigmatisation are dying for your love. Are you ready to accept these responsibilities?

Facilitator's Closing Remarks

Christ out of His love for you gave His life for you; what will you give in return this Easter? He left His Father\'s house of light, His glory-circled throne for earthly night, wandering, sad and lonely. What is so dear to you but contrary to God\'s will for your life that the Lord wants you to surrender unto Him? Will you lay it down at the feet of the Master? Christ bore your sins and suffered a lot to rescue your soul from hell; what have you borne for Him this season? Christ brought salvation full and free, His pardon and His love for you; what gifts will you bring to Christ this season?

Activity Period

  1. Identify and visit the needy in your class, show them care and love this Easter.
  2. Visit the lost and share the love of Christ to him/her.

ROAD MAP FOR DISCIPLES

Easter narratives challenge us to present ourselves as usable instruments in God\'s hand in our generation for the advancement of God\'s kingdom on earth. God is willing to make use of those who have willfully submitted themselves to His will and purpose on earth. As you have meditatively gone through the lessons each week, are you sensitive to the voice and move of God\'s Spirit and release yourself for service? This month, our focus has been on some characters who played vital roles in the Easter narratives. Simon of Cyrene and Joseph of Arimathea offered their services to Jesus; the two criminals on the cross responded to Jesus differently while one rejected Jesus the other accepted Him. We also looked at women disciples, Mary the mother of Jesus and the other Mary who demonstrated empathy, service and commitment to Jesus on His way to the cross. Finally, we learnt of "the disciple whom Jesus loved"; whose privileges attracted responsibility from his Master. The essence of the character study is to challenge us to make ourselves available to God so as to be used for His glory and for the blessings of others who God will bring our way. Are you ready for His service? Are you willing to do the will of your Lord this season? List some practical ways you can serve your Lord as a disciple this Easter.

title: god's vision for mankind (easter celebration)
message:
APRIL WEEK 1
