GOD'S VISION FOR MANKIND (EASTER CELEBRATION)

HYMN: BH 444 Christ for the Whole Wide World

SCRIPTURE: Philippians 2:5-11

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, group members should be able to:

  1. Explain the vision which God has for the redemption of humanity.
  2. State how the suffering and sacrificial death of Jesus Christ demonstrated the vision.

ICE BREAKING PERIOD: Case Study

A story was told of a young man who decided to invest everything he had to pay for the bride price of the most beautiful lady in his village. The young lady was the daughter of the village head and there was no way he could bargain the price. When the young man realised that many other suitors were interested in the young lady and that the sale of yam in his barn would not be sufficient for the bride price, he decided to `hire himself out\' on the farm of a rich man in a nearby village. After a week of hard labour, one afternoon, while making heaps on the farm of the rich man, he suddenly discovered a black pot which had been buried for many years. The pot contained some gold and other valuables which the grandfather of the rich landowner had buried, as was the custom then. When he made known his great discovery, the rich man was so happy with the young man that he decided to share part of the valuables with the young man . Thus, the young man returned to his village with sufficient jewellery and other valuables. He was able to pay the price, married the young lady, and became the richest man in his village. How can we focus more on the glorious vision of God for mankind just as the young man did to marry the beautiful lady?

Facilitator's Opening Remarks

Jesus Christ is the incarnate Word of God: by Him, and through Him, all things in heaven and on earth were made. "He is the image of the invisible God…" (Colossians 1:15-16). He had pre-existed with the Father ... as the radiance of God\'s glory and the exact representation of His being. He has been appointed the heir of all things by God\'s powerful word (Hebrews 1:2-3). The coming of Jesus Christ into the world of sin was predicated upon the eternal vision of the Godhead to save sinners, so that through the atoning death of Jesus Christ, humankind may receive pardon and eternal redemption from the powers of Satan, sin and death. Therefore, Easter is an annual celebration to commemorate Christ\'s passion and victory which had paved the way for humankind to exercise dominion over the forces of sin and Satan.

EDUCATION/INTERACTION PERIOD

  1. God's Glorious Vision for Mankind

    Vision is the bridge between the present and the future. Without it, we perish or go "unrestrained," as the New American Standard Bible puts it. Vision gives pain a purpose. God has a great plan, a vision. And that vision includes you. Yes, it does, or you would not be here. You are unique. You are different from anyone else. The great Creator, God, personally designed and made you that way. In God\'s master plan, everyone is created with many things in common with everyone else. Yet each person is distinct from any other human being. God had a vision prepared and outlined for mankind. It is the offering of and the way to eternal life in the kingdom of God: "That whoever believes in Him should not perish but have eternal life" (John 3:15). "They will come from the east and the west, from the north and the south, and sit down in the kingdom of God" (Luke 13:29). You have been called. Will you act to fulfil God\'s vision for you? Those called are invited to be living examples of a better way, a richer and fuller life. You are called to the joy of sharing God\'s vision for mankind with others, a pace-setter in high moral values and conduct, in physical and spiritual integrity. You are called to leadership through service, called to sonship (John 1:12). While still in this life, your duty is "by the mercies of God, that you present your bodies a living sacrifice, holy, acceptable to God, which is your reasonable service" (Romans 12:1). Wherever you are, work everyday to be the best person you can be, doing the best you can do with all you have to do it, to the glory of God. Yes, this is your destiny in God\'s glorious vision for mankind.

    Sharing Time: "God\'s vision, our mission," Discuss.

  2. Man Lost the Glorious Vision, Jesus Reclaims It

    Man is the unique creation of God, made in His own image (Genesis 1:27). He created them male and female as the crowning work of His creation. At creation, Man was sinless and was endowed by his Creator with freedom of choice. God\'s vision for Man was to be innocent of sin. By his free choice, Man sinned against God and brought sin into the human race. Man damaged the glorious vision of God through sin. Through yielding to the temptation of Satan, Man transgressed the law of God, and fell from his original innocence whereby his posterity inherits a nature and an environment inclined towards sin. Only the grace of God can bring Man into His holy fellowship and enable him to fulfill the creative vision of God.

    The Bible says Jesus died as a propitiation for our sins. Simply put, that means that on the cross, Jesus died to satisfy the just demands of God against sin. Because God loved us and knew that we could not pay that debt ourselves, He gave of Himself and sent His Son to pay the debt for mankind. We owed a debt we could not pay, and Jesus died to pay a debt He did not owe. The Bible says we are all sinners and that the wages of sin is death (Romans 3:23). Because Jesus lived a sinless life, He was an acceptable sacrifice for our sins. Therefore Jesus Christ died for you and me and with His blood He met the just demands of a righteous God for sin to be punished.

    Sharing Time: How are we engaging lost souls in our community and leading them to Christ?

  3. Man Was Redeemed to Restore the Glorious Vision

    Salvation involves the redemption of the whole man and is offered freely to all who accept Jesus Christ as Saviour and Lord, who by His own blood obtained eternal redemption for the believer. In its broadest sense, salvation includes regeneration, justification, sanctification and glorification. There is no salvation apart from personal faith in Jesus Christ as Lord. Mankind fell from grace to grass by his own choice. Sin separates Man from God and condemns us to eternity in hell. God loves us and sends His only Son, Jesus to die on the cross to pay the penalty for our sins. Through His death, burial and resurrection He defeated sin and death and made it possible for all who will place their trust in Him to have their sins washed away and receive eternal life. All you have to do is repent, believe and place your trust in Him today.

    Sharing Time: Will you act to fulfill God\'s vision for you? (Does anyone want to give his/her life to Jesus now?).

  4. Jesus Christ's Focus Was to Bring Sinners Back to God

    Jesus Christ, Himself being God, while living in the flesh as a human being did not find the pursuit of His eternal vision an easy task. In fact, at the onset of His ministry, He was faced with the temptation to change the focus of His vision. Matthew 4:1-11 and Luke 4:1-13 provide the account of the temptation that confronted Jesus. He had the option to choose between being a political or economic messiah, but He rejected it because it was His choice to make. That Jesus Christ eventually chose the narrow path of pain and death was not cheap or easy for him. However, He decided to endure the pain, which led to His eventual glorification. Through the resurrection of Jesus Christ, victory over death and sin were won. If Man accept Jesus Christ as Lord and Saviour, eternal and abundant life is certain.

    In order for mankind to live for the purpose he was created, they must be reconciled to God (2 Corinthians 5:19).

    Some practical steps to live for Jesus include:

    1. Have an experience of regeneration (John 3:3). This is a reference to spiritual rebirth which begins the Christian journey of faith, hope and freedom. No permanent transformation can take place in a life without a genuine experience of regeneration and redemption.
    2. Resolve to be self-controlled and disciplined (1 Corinthians 9:24-27). Life is not a bed of roses: experience of spiritual rejuvenation cannot last unless one has decided to focus only on what is essential and rewarding in life. Even, with that, there is bound to be some challenges from family members, friends, and colleagues who may feel neglected and offended by a lifestyle to pursue meaningful life goals.
    3. Determine to pursue agenda of spiritual growth/maturity (2 Peter 1:3-11). Every Christian need to pursue a lifestyle that leads to growth unto Christlikeness.

    Sharing Time: How are local churches contributing to God\'s glorious vision for kingdom expansion?

Facilitator's Closing Remarks

Man was created in God\'s image. He disobeyed God and damaged the glorious vision of God. Man was redeemed to restore the glorious vision through the coming of Jesus Christ who is our best model for excellence in godliness and victory over life challenges. Though He suffered (Hebrews 5:7), He was highly exalted and He became an example for all His followers to emulate. Today, as you decide to lead an impactful life, may God bless and prosper your efforts. Amen.

Activity Period

  1. Allow class members to share their views on how they have been keeping their vision of eternity alive.
  2. What do you consider to be the challenges to accomplishing viable vision among contemporary Christians?

title: casting vision for kingdom expansion
message:
APRIL WEEK 2

CASTING VISION FOR KINGDOM EXPANSION

HYMN: BH 407 Loyalty to Christ

SCRIPTURE: Ephesians 4:1-12

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  1. Write their vision clearly
  2. Decide how they can be helped to actualise such vision.

ICE BREAKING PERIOD: Discussion

An important topic in the study of Economics is "Division of Labour." Lead class members to discuss the importance of working with a viable team in a church or related organisation.

Facilitator's Opening Remarks

When a vision is well cast (clearly written and communicated), it compels all those to be involved in its actualisation to pursue the set objectives. Though, it is possible for an individual to work and succeed alone, it is difficult to leave a lasting legacy behind without the support and collaborative efforts of others. Today\'s discussion shall focus on the best methods/approaches to use in communicating a viable vision to a church or team members.

EDUCATION/INTERACTION PERIOD

  1. Vision: the Bridge for Kingdom's Expansion

    A vision is the painting of a future to which an individual or a group of people can commit. Vision is what must be birthed with determination and purpose, those without vision spend their lives taking the path of least resistance as they try to avoid discomfort. However, if a vision can effectively be pictured and transmitted, many are likely to adopt and follow the vision. The broad vision for the Church is seen in the Great Commission to "go into all the world and make disciples of all nations... (Matthew 28:18-20). Kris Vallotton believes "a progressive revelation of an ageless revival for our generation is growing in our hearts. It is for those who went before us and for those who are yet to be born." P. K. Bernard corroborates this assertion by affirming that, "A man without a vision is a man without a future." A man without a future will always return to his past. Proverb 29: 18 states: "Where there is no vision, the people are unrestrained, but happy is he who keeps the law." (NASU)

    No wonder Paul encourages the Christians at Ephesus to use their God-given gifts to work in unity to facilitate achieving the vision of expanding God\'s kingdom on earth (Ephesians 4:1-12). Therefore, there is a great responsibility for leaders and followers to strive toward improving the use of their spiritual gifts in cooperation with and support of others; else the church will not grow as expected.

    Sharing Time: How does your life promote or expand God\'s Kingdom?

  2. Catch the Vision

    The reality of the message Christ had been preaching for over three years must have finally dawned on the disciples when He stood before them on the Mount of Olives. Before their very eyes they watched Him ascend into heaven (Acts 1:9-11). However, His going did not result in shattered dreams. At last they had caught the vision to be His witnesses; to go and make disciples of all nations. When they caught the vision the disciples became more disciplined. We can therefore say that vision produces discipline. The disciples waited in Jerusalem for about forty days ready to receive the Holy Spirit which eventually came on them. Then they were ready to move out to carry out Jesus\' assignment. As Jesus\' disciples today, we are to catch the vision and then move ahead to continue where the early disciples had stopped. For those who have the Kingdom vision and are on mission field, for those controlled by the Holy Spirit that ignites an unquenchable passion for expanding God\'s glory, we must get beyond our religious traditions and embrace the vision to expand the kingdom of God. It does not matter our denominational persuasions or how, where, and when we fellowship; it is about our spirit\'s yearning to surrender everything for the Kingdom\'s expansion.

    Sharing Time: What fruit is your ministry bearing for God\'s glory?

  3. Changed Lives

    Notice that the disciples\' lives had changed because of vision of the commission to go into the world and make disciples of nations. Although teaching is necessary and the baptism in the Holy Spirit is essential, but without vision we can waste them all. Is the Church accomplishing great things for the Lord today with arrays of people soundly taught and full of the Holy Spirit? Why not ask God to give you a fresh vision today. Then your will and determination combined with the power of the Holy Spirit and God\'s Word will produce a force that nothing can stop. Nothing short of a radically transformed life-changing allegiance from Satan to God, death to life, flesh to the Spirit, sin to obedience, the world to the Kingdom brings glory to God. Genuine transformation results in an unquenchable passion for God and fellow man that leads to service in love. It brings a radical departure from the world and nominal Christianity to a commitment to God that leaves observers curious about the God who can change a person so significantly. As a result of true transformation, the Kingdom expands tremendously.

    Sharing Time: What can you do to be part of God\'s glorious vision for Kingdom expansion?

Facilitator's Closing Remarks

People usually commit their lives to the interests of an organisation that has a vision and the prospect of an improved future. No reasonable disciple will support any vision that will not add positive value to Kingdom\'s expansion. When members are well-motivated by visionary leadership, they will be willing to support a new idea or vision.

Activity Period

  1. List some reasons why group members may not support the vision of a leader.
  2. Suggest ways of overcoming the challenges of lack of support to the vision shared by a leader.

title: vision sustainers versus vision killers
message:
APRIL WEEK 3

VISION SUSTAINERS VERSUS VISION KILLERS

HYMN: BH 366 Blest Be the Tie

SCRIPTURE: Ecclesiastes 4:7-12; Matthew 16:13-23

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, group members should be able to:

  1. Discuss the need to carefully select their friends or counsellors.
  2. Identify those who will contribute positively to the actualisation of their God-given vision.

ICE BREAKING PERIOD: Group Discussion

No man is an island; we need the support of some people for survival or actualisation of our dreams and desired breakthroughs in life. Human beings are gifted in different areas, and the potentials of each person should be properly harnessed. What can we do to support the vision of the church leadership?

Facilitator's Opening Remarks

The Church should encourage specialisation of gifts and talents so that the strength of each person can be better appreciated. Much shall be achieved if departments can focus on how to make each person become resourceful and thus harness the potentials of each team or group member. In the same vein, persons whose weaknesses can negatively affect the overall growth and development of the Church or parachurch ministry should be persuaded on the need to amend their negative lifestyles or behaviours. Today, the discussion shall focus on how a leader can identify `vision killers\' from vision sustainers\'.

EDUCATION/INTERACTION PERIOD

In the church, no man should be considered unfit or useless: all members have a deposit of God\'s grace with which to make meaningful contribution to the overall growth of a vision. In fact, all human beings have been created to fulfil different purposes in life (Proverbs1 6:4). In the overall plans and programmes of God, each person is created to accomplish specific purpose(s), including performing seemingly unpleasant task or activity. Except where demonic influences or ungodly personal interests are involved, no right-thinking person will take interest in becoming a `vision killer\'.

  1. Vision Sustainer

    The way God has worked throughout history is in finding a person who would be a creative source of His vision. This explains why some churches suddenly come alive after long years of existence and why some become a huge success after only a few years. God always finds and plants a person through whom He could accomplish His vision. Such a person is called a visionary leader. If you take away a visionary leader from a church, it may run for a while, but it will eventually stagnate and become traditional and ineffective.

    A vision needs people to sustain it. God calls people to actually lift up His vision everyday by supporting the work. The visionary leader gets the vision organised and takes up more difficult leadership tasks; then it is up to the people we have called sustainers to carry out most of the work of the vision.

    Sharing Time: Who are the vision sustainers in your local church? Mention the category of such people?

  2. Vision or Division

    Vision has the ability to unite, yet when we look at modern-day Christianity, we find countless denominations and mission agencies with different interpretations of God\'s vision. Denominations are formed when people align themselves with the teachings of a specific person or group such as Luther, Wesley, Smyth and others

    Sometimes, denominations are formed when a pioneer hears God, proclaims the good news and pursues the things of God and thus attracts followers who want to have what he has. Such people receive the teachings of the founder and may put it into practice, but instead of growing to maturity in deeper understanding of God\'s Word, they stagnate because they have settled for a stale revelation instead of a fresh word from Lord. God\'s voice is always leading us and uniting us with His vision. Leaders are not meant to make people follow them, but rather help followers to hear God\'s voice and follow Him. When members celebrate their denomination\'s stand on certain issues rather than on the glorious vision of God, it turns such members to vision killers than vision sustainers.

    Sharing Time: What steps are you taking not to be part of disunity and division in your local church?

  3. Reasons Why a Person Can Become a `Vision Killer'

    Different reasons can be adduced to why and how a person can become a `vision killer\'. Some of the reasons are:

    1. Lack of sufficient information about the idea/vision: An individual may be acting negatively against a vision if he is not sufficiently informed, thereby constituting a clog in the wheel of progress.
    2. Failure to use effective communication skills in sharing one\'s vision: Failure on the part of the visionary leader to share or effectively communicate the vision in the manner to inspire group members can make the intended beneficiaries to oppose the effort to make the vision a reality.
    3. Ungodly lifestyle by the leader/team members: Ideally, godly visions are received by those who seek God with righteous hearts (Amos 3:7). Where the leader cannot be trusted with godly desires, the followers will hesitate to give overwhelming support to any ideas being initiated. In the same vein, where the team or group members are engaging in ungodly lifestyles or behaviour, they will find it hard to separate carnal from spiritual matters (1 Corinthians 3:1-3).
    4. Being susceptible to demonic influences: Christians are spiritual beings and must be spiritually sensitive in their reactions on all occasions. The Church of Jesus Christ is a spiritual community and should be administered in a manner that is clearly different from the worldly or secular system. Any person can be used by the devil to hinder the progress and obstruct the pathway to peace and success, even without the person knowing (cf. Matthew 16:21-23). Therefore, it is suggested that Christians should jealously guard and guide the good deposits and investments God has put in their charge.

    Sharing Time: What must you do to catch God\'s glorious vision?

  4. Tips for Avoiding `Vision Killers' and Embrace `Vision Sustainers'

    Life is full of distractions, therefore, it is important that Christian leaders and followers be determined to distinguish themselves at all times from those who are irresponsible. The followings are suggested as ways to avoid activities of `vision killers\':

    1. Be sensitive to the leading of the Holy Spirit: Oftentimes, a leader becomes depressed or confused because of pressure. However, God\'s Spirit is forever active to inspire and grant relief if one cares to follow His leading, even when it seems unreasonable.
    2. Seek friendship with only those who are serious and committed to kingdom agenda. The adage, "Show me your friend, and I will tell who you are", is forever relevant.
    3. Be preoccupied with only heavenly matters: The desire to prosper by worldly standard can become a snare believers (1Timothy 6:4-8). Engage in daily assessment of your vision and dreams to be sure they are driving you towards pursuing eternal goals only.
    4. To become a successful Christian, you must be aware of certain people in your life that have the tendency and potential to contribute to your desire to be all you can be in life, embrace such vision sustainer.
    5. To follow your dream and vision as a Christian, you must begin to identify members of your family and relatives who help your desire and dreams. They are people who encourage you to perform well and even support you spiritually, morally, and sometimes financially. These are your vision sustainers, make sure you embrace them and learn from them.

    Sharing Time: Are you willing to get on with the vision of God and be obedient followers of Christ?

Facilitator's Closing Remarks

God-given vision is a product of God working in us. He creates the vision and we just receive it; henceforth it becomes the focal point of our lives. Jesus is the Head of His Church; as the Head, His function is to direct members to work on His glorious vision. Is it possible that He will lead some in one way and others in the opposite direction for the same vision? No, God is not an author of confusion, He will always lead us together in unity of purpose under the same glorious vision. It is not appropriate for some to be vision sustainers, while others are vision killers. We all must have unanimity to achieve God\'s purpose for mankind.

Activity Period

  1. Suggest ways by which Christian leaders can avoid distraction from `vision killers.\'
  2. Lead members to pray not to work against God\'s vision for their church.

title: realising your vision for kingdom expansion
message:
APRIL WEEK 4

REALISING YOUR VISION FOR KINGDOM EXPANSION

HYMN: BH 432 Bringing in the Sheaves

SCRIPTURE: Nehemiah 2: 11-20

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  1. Support their decision to invest energy, time, talents, skills and all their potentials to actualise their dreams of working with God.
  2. Justify the need to realise their vision for the expansion of God\'s kingdom on earth.

ICE BREAKING PERIOD: Group Discussion

Who can be regarded as the person with a vision or the one without a vision? What will be the state of mind of the person without a concrete vision in life?

Facilitator's Opening Remarks

When a person\'s vision for his life is clear, then he has great power. It will be difficult to overcome such a person. The truth is that the person who has the vision of where he is heading cannot be easily confused. Likewise, if a person does not know where he is going in life, he will be confused and swept away by the ocean of life or by every wind of doctrine. It is good to have a vision. When you make your vision a reality, you will save many lives and you will be a blessing to your generation.

EDUCATION/INTERACTION PERIOD

  1. Management of Vision for Kingdom Expansion

    Marya Axner sees vision as "the big picture of the way things ought to be; your billboard image of what you are working to achieve." Ideally, having a vision is part of the responsibility of a good leader. Leadership has been variously defined. It is the ability to coordinate major activities of a group or organisation toward achieving its main objectives. According to Warren Bennis (1990) in "Managing the Dream: Training Leadership in the 21st Century" (The Magazine of Human Resource Development), "All leaders have the capacity to create a compelling vision: one that takes people to a new place; and the ability to translate that vision into reality." Today\'s discussion focuses on how a leader can work to actualise the vision of the Church or related organisation for kingdom expansion. Kris Vallotton in his article on The Power of Vision wrote:

    Vision is what we see, but it is also the way in which we see. Vision is the lens that interprets the events of our life, the way we view people and our concept of God. If we have a scratch on our glasses, it may seem like everybody around us has scratches too, but the problem actually lies with us because our vision is impaired. Jesus said that our eyes are the windows of our heart. Paul prayed that the eyes of our heart would be enlightened. In other words, we perceive with our eyes but we see with our hearts. Our minds receive images from our eyes but our heart interprets these images. If our heart becomes bitter, jealous, hurt or in some way infected, the lens of our heart is distorted.

    Sharing Time: What are ways to show that you are living with a sense of purpose?

  2. Process of Actualising Vision for Kingdom Expansion

    Certain steps are needed to be taken by the Church or team leaders in order to actualise godly vision, among which are:

    1. Discuss your vision with people. Tell team members what you are thinking. Give them your big picture. Then, listen to see if other people are concerned about the same things. See if people are interested in your picture of how things could be. The more you talk to people and listen to them, the clearer your vision will become.
    2. Develop and communicate the details. After you have tested and reshape your vision, you need to carefully work out the details. You need to give people some specifics as to what and how the vision can positively impact their lives. You also have to tell the group what steps you will take to reach the goal. Some people may view your vision as being useless until they understood some details about the likely benefits they will derive from its actualisation.
    3. Help people to own the vision. This certainly will require some efforts, but it is worth the pains. People don\'t need to agree with all the details of your vision in order to follow your lead. They will have different ideas about how to realise a vision; that is fine and healthy. But in order to work together, people need to share an overall vision and some basic goals.
    4. Be optimistic and persuasive. It takes courage to communicate a vision of what things shall be in the future. Often, it is only courageous people who see what is wrong with the implementation of a vision that successfully persuade group members about how to make necessary adjustments that new vision demands. Hence, a leader needs courage and optimism in the face of confusion and distraught.
    5. Be creative but consistent. Godly leadership requires commitment and trust by the followers. This demands time and consistency of character and personality on the part of leaders; else, people would become suspicious and easily resist all moves to pursue a genuine cause.

    Sharing Time: In what ways, can I live to actualise the goals set for my life, family, and ministry?

  3. Ways of Actualising Vision

    Different approaches can be used towards actualising the vision of the local church or related organisations. To facilitate the actualisation of a vision, there is the need to prepare "vision statement". However, some practical steps can be taken, among which are listed below:

    1. Know your organisation: People are the same everywhere, but their experiences and backgrounds can make them to behave differently. During the initial phase of formulating a vision, it is important to intentionally study to know many things about the Church or related organisation as it currently exists. In actual sense, much cannot be achieved where the leader fails to intentionally undertake a study about the history and current situation of the Church or organisation
    2. Involve critical individuals: The leader should plan to engage the support of some individuals or groups who are identified as being most critical to the Church or organisation. These `critical\' individuals can be those who are considered important, especially based on their previous records of (either positive or negative) contributions. These may be representatives of major groups in the church, especially the vocal ones.
    3. Explore the possibilities: In all instances, the vision shall attract possible changes in the spiritual, economic and social lives of the members. Thus, certain specific questions should be asked, among which are: 1) what are possible future trends of members\' needs? 2) What are the possible future expectations or requirements of team members? 3) What possible changes in the social, economic, political, or technical areas will impact the organisation?
    4. Put the vision in writing: The final step is the writing of a clear and concise `Vision Statement.\' This step requires the need to use all the information gathered from the discussions with various individuals and groups about the descriptions of the future plans as well as the intended developments and trends that will impact the church or related organisation.

    Sharing Time: What elements are necessary for successful achievement of vision in this generation?

Facilitator's Closing Remarks

To be a visionary person is to be the origin of something unique, original and groundbreaking. When any vision is actualised, it is like giving birth; an emergence or separation from the originator to exist and serve a purpose. Eventually everything works together to bring an experience that is rich. To actualise your vision, you need to follow God\'s principles, act on His Word, see the future and speak the living Word of God, then you will receive the manifestation.

Activity Period

  1. How should a leader handle discouragement, especially after having communicated or shared a vision with those who are expected to support them?
  2. Lead class members to pray for grace to identify specific people who will help in actualising their vision.

title: benefits of having vision
message:
APRIL WEEK 5

BENEFITS OF HAVING VISION

HYMN: BH 260 When We Walk with the Lord

SCRIPTURE: Proverbs 29:18

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  1. Identify and commit themselves to the task of pursuing vibrant vision.
  2. Name the benefits to enjoy in pursuing their vision.

ICE BREAKING PERIOD: Discussion

Making a `New Year Resolution\' is a common practice. However, in most cases, such resolutions fail to last except when made by those who have genuinely trusted in Jesus Christ, and rely on the power of the Holy Spirit. Human life thrives better on the joy of future rewards after a hard labour. What could make people to readily endure pains and other hardships?

Facilitator's Opening Remarks

A vision is the ability to see beyond your current reality, creating and inventing what does not now exist and becoming what you are not at present. A vision is important in all aspects of life; physical, emotional or corporate. Building your vision does not have to be difficult as long as you know exactly what you see for yourself in the future. Proverbs 29:18 provides information on the benefits of having vision. Among others, vision sharpens focus as it helps a man to labour with the desire to achieve progress. Vision also connects people to those who will become a source of blessing. In Acts 15:7-11, Peter readily supported the need to allow Gentiles to freely practise Christianity without any hindrance from Jewish leaders. That was not until he himself had been persuaded and prevailed upon through a vision from God (Acts 10:9-24). In today\'s discourse, we shall consider some benefits of having viable vision.

EDUCATION/INTERACTION PERIOD

  1. The Need for Having Vision

    Today in Nigeria, as a result of bad models in the political arena and sometimes in the Church, some young persons have been wrongly influenced to believe in `rich quick\' syndrome. Money rituals or other corrupt practices are rampant. Such experiences can only be stopped by godly leaders in churches or related organisations. The greatest antidote is by leading church members to pursue the vision of eternity. All that the Church does should be geared toward actualising the vision of saving human souls; bringing persons to the saving knowledge of Jesus Christ regardless of their colour, gender or socio-economic status.

    Human life is fraught with experiences of uncertainty. In many instances, it seems that leaders are surrounded by those who will cause them pain and frustrate their good efforts. Today, the prevailing socio-economic and political tension have also been responsible for experiences of near-confusion being witnessed in some churches or parachurches. Thus, some leaders are struggling while some are contemplating `throwing in the towel.\' Sadly some are already looking for succour elsewhere and will need persuasion and urgent reminder about the vision of where and how they started the race.

    Sharing Time: Will you act to fulfil God\'s vision for your life, family and mankind?

  2. The Benefits of Having Vision

    Every Christian leader is expected to show commitment to the task of making positive impact on their immediate community. Because the focus of the Church is different from the world, the approaches and means of actualising the vision also differ. Human society, including the Church, celebrates only the achievers: no one pays much attention to the loser. In fact, there is a great difference between success and failure. Success usually attracts many friends but failure is an orphan. However, success does not come cheaply; it is mostly the result of hard work. Before a leader can experience breakthrough in the course of pursuing viable goals/vision, much is involved.

    The world is full of distractions and Christian leaders are not totally immune to its influences. In some cases, to experience failure is not an absence of true or genuine vision but the lack of understanding about how to overcome distractions. Some benefits of having vision are listed below:

    1. Vision helps in designing life\'s goals and purpose. All men are created by God to fulfil specific goals in life. The greatest tragedy in life is not the failure to make wealth, but the failure to fulfill divine agenda.
    2. Vision prevents a pursuit of unprofitable goals in life. No man can achieve everything the heart craves, but to avoid wasteful labour, Christian leaders should pursue only worthwhile goals that emanates from vibrant vision received from God.
    3. Vision protects leaders from distraction and near-confusion. There are instances when only vibrant vision safeguards the efforts of both the leader and team members from losing focus.
    4. Vision creates and multiplies chances of success. "If you do not stand for something, you will fall for everything" is a popular adage. With the pursuit of a vision, one\'s joy can be made full, but, without vibrant vision, success in any task or effort is only accidental.
    5. Every dream and idea is loaded toward attaining that vision. The vision gives you the reason to push through and to put your heart and soul behind what you are doing. Your reason can give you the strength to row that oar one more time when it seems all hope is lost.
    6. You are less likely to look back with regrets. Can you compare the number of times you have regretted doing something versus not doing anything? By stepping into the fullness of what we want we are allowing ourselves a fulfilling life, but to step back from what is in our hearts is only to set ourselves up for regret.
    7. Vision gives you hope. Expectation has a vision in mind and without it there\'s nothing to realise.
    8. You will never be the same. May be you know that a rubber band once stretched can never return to its original dimensions. You will be catapulted into a new you and a new experience with a vision that has come to fruition.

    Sharing Time: What can be done to earn the benefits of vision and actualise the expansion of God\'s kingdom?

Facilitator's Closing Remarks

Let me close with the words of Josh Hinds who says, "Having a vision that sets your life on fire is a golden ticket to the top of that mountain. And guess what? You have this in you already. There is a spark, there is flame, and once you uncover it you\'re going to see that there is an amazing world waiting for you." Vision empowers and enables leaders and members to overcome unnecessary distraction that could lead to a waste of time, energy, and resources. The benefits of having vibrant vision are unlimited.

Activity Period

  1. Encourage members to share their experiences of benefitting from a task after a genuine commitment to their vision
  2. Lead group members to pray for more grace to keep to their vision of making positive impact on their community.
  3. The Church is the hope of the world and men are the hope of the Church. God is looking for men. God is looking for you. Will you be like Isaiah and say to the Lord, "Here am I, send me!" (Isaiah 6:8).

ROAD MAP FOR DISCIPLES

Vision helps you to design a fulfilling life. Vision is a great tool that helps you to actively work on your passion and to create successful work around it. As God had vision for mankind, we must have vision for our life. . When, as Christ\'s disciples you have a mental picture of what should g be, you are less likely to give up on your dream. By keeping the ideal picture in mind, you are able to keep yourself motivated even when the going gets tough. Having a heart-centered vision makes you come alive because it opens up possibility, creates hope and inspires meaning. Without a God-given vision, we will waste energy pursuing frivolous things and be at variance with God\'s purpose for our lives individually and corporately. Unless we have vision for making disciples, we will fail to relate well with new believers and help them mature in the Lord. Being unrestrained, we may be unable to choose the best over the good. Not only will we fail to disciple others, but we will also find excuses for being lazy and not disciplining ourselves spiritually.

title: history and importance of father's day
message:
MAY WEEK 1

HISTORY AND IMPORTANCE OF FATHER'S DAY

HYMN: BH 252 Faith of Our Fathers

SCRIPTURE: Exodus. 12:14-20; 43-49

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  1. Explain briefly the history of the Father\'s Day in the Nigerian Baptist Convention.
  2. List the importance of Father\'s Day to fathers, family and the church.
  3. Make commitment to make the programme more enriching.

ICE BREAKING PERIOD: Playlet

Mr Agboola: Good morning, Mr Adeseun. This year\'s Father\'s Day celebration will be coming up in two weeks time. How are you preparing for it?

Mr Adeseun: What concerns me about Father\'s Day? Is it not for the grandpas in the church? I have just got married and I have no children yet, so why should I bother about Father\'s Day?

Mr Agboola: Ah! Mr. Adeseun, you have got it wrong. Father\'s Day is not for only the grandpas. It is designed for all married men; young and old, whether they have children or not. Surely, you have many things that concerns you with it. One, you are a good husband who deserves honour. Two, you are a child to your father and you have to honour your father. Three, you have children in the church who are looking up to you as a role model do etc. Can you see, you have a lot to do with it.

Mr Adeseun: Ah, thank you my brother! I didn\'t see it that way before. Now I will start preparing very well for it.

Facilitator's Opening Remarks

There is history behind every event in the church. Ignorance of this history may lead us to have negative attitude towards the annual events. It may also cause inadequate preparation and shoddy presentation of such programmes. But observing the annual event reflectively enables us to appreciate the legacy bequeathed by the Baptist forbears, preserve the tradition and transfer it to the next generation. Today, one of the annual programmes in the church is Father\'s Day, an annual church programme aimed at honouring fathers. How and why did it begin?

EDUCATION/INTERACTION PERIOD

  1. What Is Father's Day?

    Father\'s Day is the day set aside annually by the Men\'s Missionary Union to honour and celebrate Christian fathers for their selfless and sacrificial effort to provide and cater for their families and to be who God wants them to be. In 1909, Miss Sonora Louis Smart Dodd was inspired by Miss Ann Javis\'s effort to promote Mother\'s Day in the United States of America. She reasoned that Father\'s Day could also be commemorated to honour her father, Mr William Jackson Smart who single-handedly raised her and her six siblings after the death of their mother during childbirth. Her campaign caught the attention of the Spokane Ministerial Association and Young Men\'s Christian Association (YMCA) in Spokane. Since 1966, the American President, Woodrow Wilson approved this idea and in 1972, President Nixon established a permanent national observance of Father\'s Day on the third Sunday of June every year.

    Sharing Time: In what ways can we honour our fathers before and after Father\'s Day?

  2. Significance of Father's Day

    Father\'s Day has become one of the major programmes organised by Men\'s Missionary Union of the Nigerian Baptist Convention. The day is set aside to minister to the needs of fathers in different local churches. The following are the importance of Father\'s Day:

    1. The day reminds every father of their uniqueness in God\'s redemptive plan: There are some fathers who do not value themselves as God\'s agent. Their experiences may have given them a wrong view of an ideal father which affects how they look at themselves and others. The objective of Father\'s Day is to remind every father of his uniqueness in God\'s redemptive plan and the need to support church work. In the Bible, fatherhood is God\'s idea (Genesis 1:28-29). It has worth. Fathers like Adam, Abraham, Isaac, Jacob, David, Joseph and others played vital roles in fulfilling God\'s redemptive plan for humankind.
    2. The day encourages Churches and families to honour all fathers: Father\'s Day is a day set aside to honour all fathers, young and old who demonstrate Christian virtue such as care, hard work, foresight, diligence, succour and perseverance towards their families. The honour goes not only to those who have given birth to children but also to those who nurtured and reared children as if they were their own. Mothers, children and relatives are encouraged to send words of encouragement to such fathers in order to appreciate them and their worth.
    3. The day re-emphasises the need to rely on God in fulfilling the roles of fatherhood: It is extremely difficult to be a father in this 21st century. Relying on God, however, makes it achievable. The programme activities for the day is attuned to correct, train, and equip fathers through the knowledge of God. The activities are meant to build the virtues of righteousness in the heart of fathers in order to help them make right choices in life. The day challenges the fathers to know God as the Source of life. The theme of the Father\'s Day for each year serves as the basis for the pastor\'s message. It gives fathers the opportunity to evaluate their lives and realign themselves into God\'s plan.
    4. The day promotes the ministry of Men's Missionary Union in recruiting and integrating fathers to church life: There are some men in the church who are not involved actively in MMU because they do not see anything worthwhile to gain from it. A good presentation of the Father\'s Day programme can serve as an eye-opener to challenge their mindset and become active members.

    Sharing Time: In what area has Father\'s Day celebration added value to your life, fatherhood, and the church?

Facilitator's Closing Remarks

Our negative attitude to annual events in our churches becomes positive when we are well informed about how and why they began. There should be adequate preparation and presentation of such programmes to touch lives. Observing and reflecting on the annual event may enable us to appreciate the legacy bequeathed by our Baptist forbears, preserve it and transfer it to the next generation.

Activity Period

  1. In what ways do today\'s fathers regard themselves as God\'s representatives?
  2. Why is Father\'s Day losing its spiritual significance in some Baptist churches? How do we solve the problem?

title: history and significance of mother's day
message:
MAY WEEK 2

HISTORY AND SIGNIFICANCE OF MOTHER'S DAY

HYMN: BH 487 Faith of Our Mothers

SCRIPTURE: 2 Timothy 1:5

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, members should be able to:

  1. Give the definition of the term "Mother\'s Day."
  2. Explain briefly the history of how the Mother\'s Day began.
  3. List the values of the Mother\'s Day to families, the church and the society and make commitment to have positive attitude towards making the programme enriching.

ICE BREAKING PERIOD: Sharing Testimony

Invite two unmarried young ladies and two married women to come out and share with the class how Mother\'s Day celebrations done in the past have blessed their lives. They should also express their views - whether Mother\'s Day celebration is worth doing or not. (This should not exceed 5 minutes).

Facilitator's Opening Remarks

The role that Christian mothers play in the up-keep of the home, caring for the fathers and training their children cannot be overemphasised. Even in the Church, mothers play vital role in teaching and mentoring young girls and young ladies. Bearing this in mind, indeed, mothers are worthy of honour. Fathers, children, and the Church need to appreciate motherhood. Mothers too need to honour one another. There is need for Mother\'s Day celebration.

EDUCATION/INTERACTION PERIOD

  1. What is Mother\'s Day?

    Mother\'s Day is the day set aside annually by the Women\'s Missionary Union of the Nigerian Baptist Convention to honour and celebrate Christian mothers for their selfless effort to make their homes be what God wants it to be. The records of Baptist Women\'s Missionary Union of Nigeria showed that Mother\'s Day was first observed on May 10, 1908 in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, United States of America. When the mother of Miss Ann Jarvis died, she decided to honour her. Through her efforts, a day was set aside to honour mothers was set aside. Now, Mother\'s Day is observed throughout the world. Special acts of kindness are shown to mothers to demonstrate love and appreciation to them. In Nigeria, Mother\'s Day was first observed on the second Sunday in May, 1924. Then, there was no special programme prepared for it. Churches just observed it as they desired and a special offering was taken. There was no knowledge of a prepared programme until 1931 when Miss N.C. Young prepared a Mother\'s Day Programme. Mother\'s Day booklet has become one of the regular programmes produced and published by Baptist Women\'s Missionary Union of Nigeria.

    Sharing Time: How can Mother\'s Day be made attractive to newly married women who came from non-Baptist background?

  2. Significance of Mother's Day

    Stated below are some of the important things to know about Mother\'s Day:

    1. The day reminds every mother of her uniqueness in God\'s redemptive plan: An aspect of African cultural view of a mother can devalue her worth and dignity. For example, a mother is often regarded as property or someone who cannot keep a secret. In the Bible, motherhood is God\'s idea (Genesis 2:18). She has worth. Mothers like Sarah, Jochebed, Ruth, Hannah, and Mary played vital roles in bringing God\'s redemptive plan to pass. Mother\'s Day thus reminds every mother of her uniqueness in God\'s redemptive plan and the need to support church work.
    2. The day encourages the Church and the family to honour all mothers: It is a day set aside to honour all mothers who demonstrate Christian virtues such as care, hard work, foresight, diligence, succour and perseverance towards their families. The honour goes not only to those who have given birth to children but also to those who nurtured and reared children as if they were their own. Husbands, children and relatives are encouraged to send words of encouragement and gifts to such mothers in order to encourage them to do more.
    3. The day challenges mothers on their responsibilities in raising godly children for a better society: It is extremely difficult to be a mother in this 21st century. In response to this, the pastor uses the opportunity to challenge mothers to depend on God to achieve their God-given responsibilities. The basis of the pastor\'s message is the yearly theme of WMU. It gives an opportunity for mothers to evaluate their lives and realign themselves into God\'s plan.
    4. The day promotes the ministry of WMU in the growth of the local church: Through the programme, the church leadership is adequately informed of the objectives of the WMU as an auxiliary of the Nigerian Baptist Convention in equipping Baptist women for kingdom expansion.

    Sharing Time: How can Mother\'s Day celebration become more enriching in our local churches?

Facilitator's Closing Remarks

Mother\'s Day is both historical and spiritual. It is beyond mere celebration but a way of encouraging mothers to be faithful in their God-given assignment as wives and mothers. It also serves as a way of preparing young ladies for their future homes. Church leadership should therefore give full support to the WMU so that the women can fulfil their responsibility of encouraging one another to be what God created them to be.

Activity Period

  1. To what extent has Mother\'s Day celebration added value to their various families and the church?
  2. Visit a newly married woman in your church, tell her the history and the significance of Mother\'s Day celebration and encourage her to join the WMS of the church.

title: history and purpose of children's day
message:
MAY WEEK 3

HISTORY AND PURPOSE OF CHILDREN'S DAY

HYMN: BH 512 Jesus Loves Me

SCRIPTURE: Psalm 127: 3-5

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, members should be able to:

  1. Explain briefly how Children\'s Day celebration began in Nigeria and in the Nigerian Baptist Convention.
  2. List the values of Children\'s Day to children, families, the Church and the society.
  3. Make a commitment to develop positive attitude toward the event and to fully support the programme.

ICE BREAKING PERIOD: Brainstorming

Let a member share with the class the significances of Children\'s Day celebration in Nigeria.

Facilitator's Opening Remarks

Children are unique and important in God\'s plan. They are God\'s heritage and reward. They are blessings to parents, families, Church, community and the society at large. They need to be well cared for, protected, and valued beyond other possessions. Because of children\'s importance, many countries of the world including Nigeria have special days when children are celebrated. The Nigerian Baptist Convention also has a special Sunday designated for children in Baptist churches. Today we want to learn about the history, and significance of Children\'s Day in Nigeria and in our great Convention.

EDUCATION/INTERACTION PERIOD

  1. What Is Children\'s Day?

    Children\'s Day is the day set aside once in a year to celebrate children and to remind parents of the importance of training and taking good care of children as the future leaders. Children are to be cared for physically, mentally, socially and spiritually. The Nigerian government has set aside May 27 as the day to celebrate children. The idea of marking Children\'s Day was adopted and proclaimed on November 20, 1954 by United Nations General Assembly and the very first Universal Children\'s Day was celebrated all over the world in October 1955. After 1959, it started being celebrated on the 20th of November, as that day marked the anniversary when the declaration of the Rights of the Child was adopted. Different countries celebrate Children\'s Day on different days "to promote mutual exchange and understanding among children" and "initiate action to benefit and promote the welfare of the world\'s children." The day is a public holiday for children and - gathered at different places for special march by various schools and the best school is honoured.

  2. Children's Day in the Nigerian Baptist Convention

    The Nigerian Baptist Convention started to observe Children\'s Day through the Family Life Education Division, then known as Children\'s Ministry Division of the Christian Education Department with Rev. Dr Comfort Ayanrinola as the coordinator of that division. Now the programme is being prepared on leaflets and distributed to the Nigerian Baptist Convention churches as a guide to celebrate the Children\'s Day at church level. Several children programmes such as drama, talent show, music are organised to educate, minister, and pray for children on that day. Children\'s Day service/celebration in the local church is slated for Sunday preceding the May 27th which is the National Children\'s Day. It is usually a special day of recognition for children in the Nigerian Baptist Convention churches.

  3. What Is the Significance of Children's Day?
    1. The day opens the eyes of stakeholders to the challenges confronting Nigerian children

      It is important to note that today\'s children face social challenges such as hunger, rejection, sexual abuse, broken homes, lack of trust, insecurity and wrong peer pressure. Some are paid a token to hawk in the scorching sun. Some are raped and dehumanised. One of the objectives of the National Children\'s Day is to create the awareness of these challenges and to make the concerned stakeholders to provide solutions to these challenges.

    2. The day emphasises the biblical view of the importance of children in the society

      Every child is God\'s gift to the world. Psalm 127:3 states that every child has value because he/she comes from God: "... children are a heritage from the Lord." This biblical view nullifies the preference for the male child among some Christians due to the influence of the African belief system. The fact is children are God\'s idea. Therefore, Children\'s Day provides an opportunity to emphasise the uniqueness of both gender as God\'s seed to cherish and to nurture.

    3. The day creates an awareness of the need for quality educational programmes in early childhood to the church leadership (Deuteronomy 9:4-6; Proverbs 22:6)

      Secular educational system is exposing our children to different knowledge through phone, cable television, the internet, etc. The programme of activities conducted on Children\'s Day is to correct, train and inform both parents and leaders through the Word of God. The activities are meant to early build up the virtues of righteousness in the heart of the child as early as possible to help them make right choices in life. The day challenges the children to know God as the Source of life.

    4. The day promotes the children's ministry of the Church to provide resources to meet the physical, spiritual emotional, mental and social needs of the children

      Through Children\'s Day programme, the church leadership is adequately informed of the objectives of the division in order to support them in ensuring that children are nurtured in the way of the Lord.

    5. The day emphasises the role of family and church in the development of the child

      The children are born into a specific family. It means the first school a child attends is the home. A Christian family thus becomes the first contact a child has with God through the attitude and behaviour of the parents. Children\'s Day programme, therefore, is aimed at challenging the parents to be portraits of godliness to the child in words and deeds. It also stresses the need for them to bring up the child so that his heart will be opened to God early.

Facilitator's Closing Remarks

Children are very important to God. If the nations of the world can support Children\'s Day, the church and her leadership should not do less. We must give full support to the Children\'s Ministry of the church by being actively involved in the children\'s programmes, including the Children\'s Day celebration.

Activity Period

  1. What has been your attitude towards the children\'s ministry in your church?
  2. Advise a member of another church in your neighbourhood on the importance of children\'s ministry.

title: significance of youth week celebration in the nigerian baptist convention
message:
MAY WEEK 4

SIGNIFICANCE OF YOUTH WEEK CELEBRATION IN THE NIGERIAN BAPTIST CONVENTION

HYMN: BH 423 Arise, O Youth of God

SCRIPTURE: Ecclesiastes 12:1; Proverbs 1:1-8; 3:1-2

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  1. Explain briefly how the Youth Week began.
  2. List the values of the Youth Week to children, families, the Church and the society.
  3. Make commitment to develop a positive attitude towards the event and make the programme enriching.

ICE BREAKING PERIOD: Opinion Sharing

Let two men and two women come out and share their opinion on the annual Youth Week programme of the Convention and how they think it can be made more enriching.

Facilitator's Opening Remarks

Some of us perform several annual events in our churches without reflecting about their values. The effect is that the commitment to such programme reduces remarkably. If we are thoughtful in observing the annual event, it may enable us to appreciate the legacy entrusted to us by our predecessors and preserve the tradition for the next generation. Youth Week celebration is such an annual event. The aim of today\'s programme is to examine the significance of the annual programme and the challenges it brings to the local Baptist church. The programme is in question and answer\'s form.

EDUCATION/INTERACTION PERIOD

  1. What Is NBC Annual Youth Week?

    Annual Youth Week is a week-long programme designed by the Youth Ministry Division of Youth and Students Ministries Department of the Nigerian Baptist Convention for the youth in our local churches to develop their ministering skills and potentials, as well as to minister to their spiritual, physical, health and social needs. Since the 1960s, the Nigeria Baptist Convention has established the Youth Ministry as a unit to mobilise Baptist youths towards taking the gospel to all who have not heard it. Another objective is to inculcate Christian disciplines in the spiritual, mental, emotional and physical development of the youths. To achieve these objectives, an annual Youth Week celebration in local Baptists churches has become a strategy. The church pastor/leader relinquishes his authority for a week to a youth pastor in June every year. NBC Youth Ministry designs a weeklong thematic programme from which other sub-themes in the area of marital, vocational, physical, intellectual, etc., are derived.

  2. Why Youth Ministry?

    There is a need for effective youth ministry in our local Baptist churches today because of the following reasons:

    1. God commands it (Ecclesiastes 12:1; Proverbs 1:1-8; 3:1-2). Being a wise ruler, Solomon did not want the youth to be influenced by the evil culture of the society. His instructions contained the content of Christian education for today\'s youth. Daniel lived in Babylon, a heathen society but his Jewish education in his tender age informed his decision that made him to stand out (Daniel 1:7).
    2. The contemporary society demands it: Today\'s youths are living in a world characterised by violence in form of kidnapping, ritual killing, savagery, rape and craving for materialism. The moral laxity has negative influence on the Baptist youth and the church needs to respond.

    Sharing Time: Why are some youths only committed to church during the Youth Week celebration?

  3. What are the Significance of NBC Annual Youth Week celebration?

    There are values, which the Baptist youth and the Church can derive from the annual Youth Week celebration:

    1. Bridging the generation gap between youths and adults: Generation gap refers to age differences between adults and youth. This can be the cause of Church conflict because each of them look at the same issue from different standpoint. The annual Youth Week programme can provide an opportunity to bridge the gap through lively interaction between the adult member of the church and the youth. Doctrinal issues such as Baptist distinctives (autonomy of the local church, separation of the church and state) and the Baptist beliefs on Holy Spirit, prayer, speaking in tongues, and marriage, can be discussed in an atmosphere of love between the adult and the youth.
    2. Understanding youth lfe: The world of youth is different from that of the adult. Youth Week celebration provides an eye-opener to the church leadership on the worldview, language, social, intellectual, spiritual, physical and emotional needs of the contemporary youth for the church to effectively minister to them. The weekly activities such as Bible study, marriage talk, career choice and question time provide a window into youth life in order to reach out to them according to their level of understanding.
    3. Guiding youth to make right decisions: Due to their inexperience, Youth Week celebration provides an avenue to give guidance to youth in acquiring entrepreneurship skills and choosing a life partner. When adults share their experiences, the youths are guided to make wise choices. The right interpretation of the Bible can also guide them in this area.
    4. Discovering their leadership potential: An annual Youth Week celebration in local churches allow one of the youthss to be the "church pastor" for a week. The church leader relinquishes his pastoral authority for a week to a youth pastor. He preaches on a Sunday service and coordinates the weekly activities. Some youths have been touched by the report of mission effort to the unreached. God uses this programme to prepare them for a future assignment. History has shown that today\'s denominational leaders were once youth pastors.
    5. Recruiting youths into church life: Some youths become active church members through the Youth Week celebration. Drama, variety night, sport activities, and visitation to Motherless Homes have attracted some of them to the Youth Week after which they turn out to be strong church members.

Facilitator's Closing Remarks

Youth week is not a mere celebration but a way to help youths discover their potentials. The church must encourage such event for empowerment of our youth for a better future. This will enhance healthy church growth and kingdom expansion. There are significant lessons to learn from the annual church events. The church pastor should educate the church constantly on the reasons for the celebration and the impact on the individual and the entire church.

Activity Period

  1. How can the Youth Week celebration be more spiritually-enriching?
  2. Share with a youth in your church who does not usually attend youth fellowship of the importance of youth ministry and the significances of annual Youth Week.

ROAD MAP FOR DISCIPLES

For the past four weeks, we have been discussing about specific annual celebrations in the Nigerian Baptist Convention. What has been your disposition towards the Mother\'s Day celebration as a woman in this local church? As a father, have you been fully involved in Father\'s Day celebration? What about the Children\'s Day? Do you support the children\'s ministry of your church? Are you an encourager for the youth in your church? Think about whether you are still on track as far as this lesson is concerned. Every Baptist member must participate in these spiritual awakening, educative, and inspiring celebrations.

title: recognition and respect for human resources
message:
JUNE WEEK 1

RECOGNITION AND RESPECT FOR HUMAN RESOURCES

HYMN: BH 8 All Things Bright and Beautiful

SCRIPTURE: Romans 12:3-13

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, disciples should be able to:

  1. Explain why it is important to value people.
  2. Determine to give people their due respect.

ICE BREAKING PERIOD: Case Study

A first-time car owner went to the mechanic workshop to fix a fault in the car. One getting there, the mechanic discovered that it was an electrical fault, but he did not want the car owner to know that auto electricians are important in car maintenance. He therefore made every effort to fix the fault to no avail. While the car owner was getting worried, an electrician turned to the mechanic to find out what was wrong with the car. In a moment, the electrician fixed the fault. He then explained to the man that it was an electrical fault and not a mechanical fault. In view of this case study, discuss the importance of recognition and respect for human resources.

Facilitator's Opening Remarks

Every human being has a sense of self worth. When that self-worth is recognised and respected, it gives room for cordial relationship and more usefulness. But when an individual\'s self worth is condemned, it gives room to rebellion, acrimony and poor performance. As disciples of Jesus Christ, there is the need to know how to boost the self-worth of people around us by giving them their due recognition and respect.

EDUCATION/INTERACTION PERIOD

  1. Realisation that Individuals are Distinct

    In all human institutions, individuals are distinct. No single individual has all that it takes for an organisation to function maximally. Hence, the different personalities that make up the organisation deserve due recognition and respect. To ignore this fact about human management is to give room for ill feeling, gossip and sometimes strike action. There was a time when petroleum tankers\' drivers went on strike in Nigeria, and one of them said that even though he had no formal education, together with his colleagues, they had what it took to ground the nation. The truth is what such people are looking for is recognition.

    Sharing Time: In what ways can parents give recognition and respect to their children?

  2. Due Regard through Public Recognition

    Majority of people appreciate it when they are given due regard through public recognition. Both in the secular and religious circles, such recognition engender better relationship and performance. Just imagine a convocation ceremony of a university without the lecturers who trained the graduands being recognised, it may affect the ceremony negatively. As occasion demands, human managers should give due regards through public recognition.

    Sharing Time: What can church leaders do for church members to feel recognised and respected?

  3. Giving Credit to a Deserving Person

    There are times when an organisation achieves a great feat due to the effort of an individual or a group. While the organisation is celebrating such a great feat, it is important for those who played prominent roles to be given credit in form of special recognition. This is more important if the achievements of the organisation attract praises and award from an external body. When credit is given to a deserving person, his/her morale is boosted.

    Sharing Time: In corporate organisations, how can employer show respect to employee?

Facilitator's Closing Remarks

Humanly speaking, it is easy to recognise and show respect to highly placed people. But people who deserve recognition in our sphere of influence are sometimes neglected. As parents in the home, we need to give attention to a child who deserves some special recognition. In the church, there are people who serve in special committees; thereby making significant contributions, they should be recognised and commended. To all administrators and managers in secular and religious circles, recognition and respect for people is important for maximum performance.

Activity Period

  1. In the leadership position you are occupying presently, how are you treating your followers? Pray for grace to henceforth always recognise and respect your followers.
  2. A member should share an experience of how he/she was recognised and shown respect by the leadership of an organisation that he/she belongs to, and the outcome.

title: delegating power and authority
message:
JUNE WEEK 2

DELEGATING POWER AND AUTHORITY

HYMN: BH 435 To the Work

SCRIPTURE: Exodus 18:13-27

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, disciples should be able to:

  1. Explain what delegation of power and authority means;
  2. Give examples of how to delegate power and authority.

ICE BREAKING PERIOD: Case Study

A couple completed their house and moved in. When it was Sunday, they worshipped in a nearby church hoping to join their membership. But their experience there discouraged them, forcing them to go back to their church. Why? The pastor of the church where they worshipped did not know how to delegate responsibility. He felt that nobody could do anything well, so he alone was operating the sound system, playing the drum, directing people to their seats etc. He was so disorganised that visitors hardly returned to the church. What is the appropriate thing the pastor ought to do? The lesson of today will enlighten us.

Facilitator's Opening Remarks

To delegate power and authority means to allow someone to function or act on one\'s behalf. When a leader, administrator or manager has several responsibilities to carry out, it is wise for him or her to ask some of his or her subordinates to take charge of some of the assignments. Human managers should recognise the potentials of people around them and be able to engage them as need arises.

EDUCATION/INTERACTION PERIOD

  1. The Limitation of a Single Person:

    Someone may be very intelligent, wealthy, strong and influential. But with all his or her abilities, he or she has limitations. These limitations make it important for such a person to share responsibilities with others. Nobody can do it all.

    Sharing Time: What can we do in a situation where a single person occupies many positions in a church while others are spectators? How can we address this imbalance?

  2. Identify and Invest in Capable Hands:

    The counsel of Jethro to Moses is very apt. Moses was counselled to look for capable hands to help him in administering justice to the Israelites (Exodus 18:19-21). In some organisations, the capable hands may not be available. But human managers should be able to discover potentials and invest in them to make them capable. Jesus did that to the twelve disciples who became Apostles.

    Sharing Time: In a church where members are idle what should the leadership do to delegate authority?

  3. Maximising Potentials of Team Members:

    A leader may not appreciate the potentials of team members until he or she gives them opportunity to perform. Jesus Christ gave opportunity to His disciples to do the very things He was doing. They preached, ministered to the sick and the demon possessed. When they failed, He tutored them until they mastered the work. Human managers should maximise the potentials of their team members by allowing them to do the work.

    Sharing Time: In a family where children are not exposed to work, what is the outcome?

  4. The Need for Moderation in Delegating Responsibility:

    The willing horse should not be driven to death. When a manager overburdens a subordinate with assignments, it backfires. Also, a manager who continues to delegates all his or her responsibilities may become a stranger in the establishment. As much as it is important for leaders to delegate power and authority to their followers, they should not abandon their own responsibility, and they should not overwork their followers.

    Sharing Time: What happens when a leader totally delegate his or her duties without a sense of responsibility?

Facilitator's Closing Remarks

In one way or the other, we are all leaders and managers. When you are working and there are people around you, you should know how to share your work with them. At times you may need to pay for the services of those who are helping you to work. If you are bent on doing everything alone, you may waste more time and energy and sometimes breakdown.

Activity Period

  1. Someone should share an experience of how delegation of power helps in training manpower.
  2. Are you a leader who knows it all or one who abandons your responsibility in the name of delegation? Consider making a positive change.
  3. Pray for grace to discover special potentials in your followers and to develop such potentials for God\'s glory.

title: motivation as key ingredient in human management
message:
JUNE WEEK 3

MOTIVATION AS KEY INGREDIENT IN HUMAN MANAGEMENT

HYMN: BH 438 Make Me a Channel of Blessing

SCRIPTURE: 2 Kings 6:1-7

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  1. Recall how to motivate those who work under them;
  2. Demonstrate how they will encourage their subordinates for greater performance.

ICE BREAKING PERIOD: Group Discussion

Members should be divided into two groups; while one group discusses a family setting where children are motivated, the other group should discuss a family setting where children are not motivated.

Facilitator's Opening Remarks

To motivate means to encourage or spur someone through a kind gesture. In human management it is very important to deliberately use kind gesture to encourage those who work for us. When people are well motivated, their input is enhanced. In our lesson today, the emphasis is on motivation and its importance. This is to enable those in leadership position never to ignore it. We shall be discussing the need for motivation, different ways of motivating people and the effects of motivation.

EDUCATION/INTERACTION PERIOD

  1. The Need for Motivation in Human Management:

    In every human environment, the need for motivation cannot be overemphasised. The following are some of the advantages of motivation:

    1. Motivation in human management makes people to feel valued. Frankly, people resist every attempt to devalue or dehumanize them. This is why there are unions in some work places that ensure their members are respected and honoured. When management gives incentives to motivate the staff, they feel esteemed.
    2. When people are motivated, they do not feel used. Some human managers love to use their subordinates to achieve their goals without any incentive. When the subordinates discover that they are being used, their psyches and inputs are negatively affected.
    3. When people are motivated, they are propelled to work better. It is natural for people who are well motivated to work better for greater productivity.

    Sharing Time: As Christians, if we are not motivated in our workplace as we expect, what should we do?

  2. The Ways to Motivate in Human Management

    Workers can be motivated in the following ways:

    1. Promotion in a work environment, when workers are promoted as and when due, with the entitlements, they are motivated.
    2. Appreciation and awards there should be occasion for long service award, or appreciation for a job well done. It may be in writing, cash gift or public recognition.
    3. Loan facility when workers have access to loan with little or no interest, they are motivated.
    4. In-service training and scholarship workers, who are given opportunity to be upgraded, are motivated for better performances.

    Sharing Time: A member should share how he/she is being motivated in his or her family.
    Also, two members should share how they are being motivated in their workplaces.

  3. Effects of Motivation in Human Management:

    The disposition of people matters in their productivity. When people are happy and free of tension, they are more valuable to the organisation. It means that when people are motivated, their dispositions are enhanced, and the organisation is better for it.

    Sharing Time: In a situation where employers motivate their employees, what happens to the productivity of the employees?

Facilitator's Closing Remarks

Human beings are sensitive to manage. If human managers want to get the best out of the people are under them, the issue of motivation should be taken seriously. However, as Christians, we should understand our work environment very well so that we will not expect unrealistic motivations.

Activity Period

Members should suggest ways that people can be better motivated.

title: trust and acceptance as necessary factors in human management
message:
JUNE WEEK 4

TRUST AND ACCEPTANCE AS NECESSARY FACTORS IN HUMAN MANAGEMENT

HYMN: BH 258 'Tis So Sweet to Trust in Jesus

SCRIPTURE: Genesis 39:1-6

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, disciples should be able to:

  1. Explain the values of trust and acceptance in human management;
  2. Apply the values in their relationship with other people as a leader or subordinate.

ICE BREAKING PERIOD: Case Study

The Scripture for this lesson is about Joseph and his master Potiphar. In view of today\'s topic, members should discuss the action of Potiphar and that of Joseph with regard to trust and acceptance.

Facilitator's Opening Remarks

In every relationship, trust or lack of it determines the level of closeness. There are people who live together or work in the same office, but are not close. It takes trust and acceptance for human managers or leaders to commit important assignments into the hands of their subordinates.
