On the other hand, when one is trusted and accepted, he or she should justify the trust.

EDUCATION/INTERACTION PERIOD

  1. What Trust and Acceptance Mean in Human Management

    In human management, trust and acceptance means to be convinced that someone is genuine, sincere and capable. In other words, trust and acceptance are when a leader has confidence in someone and entrusts responsibilities to him or her.

    Sharing Time: Share your personal experiences of how trust and acceptance helped you to serve well.

  2. The Value of Trust and Acceptance in Human Management

    In any human organisation, when there are trust and acceptance, there is a sense of belonging. It makes the subordinate to see himself or herself as part of the organisation. Also, trust and acceptance give room for people to make use of their potentials. A leader may not know what a follower is capable of doing until there is trust. When people are trusted and accepted, they are given room to prove themselves.

    Sharing Time: What are the values of trust and acceptance in any establishment?

  3. Some Practical Approaches to Trust and Acceptance

    Every relationship begins at a point. For trust and acceptance to take place, there should be communication. A manager or leader who has a new staff member should take time to interact with him or her. Allow him or her to talk about himself or herself. Also, trust and acceptance demand that the leader should take the subordinate as he claims to be, until proven otherwise. Trust and acceptance should entail delegation of duties.

    Sharing Time: Discuss ways leaders should demonstrate trust and acceptance. Also, members should share, with practical examples, negative effects of lack of trust and acceptances.

  4. Necessary Caution on Trust and Acceptance:

    While trust and acceptance are important in human management, there are necessary cautions. Leaders should allow trust to build up with time, rather than being too quick to entrust sensitive responsibility to erring follower. Also, there is the need to test claims by an individual so that the genuineness of such claims may be proven. These cautions have become inevitable due to the high level of betrayal of trust.

    Sharing Time: In church work, what can members do to guard against betrayal of trust as not to damage the unity and love in the church?

Facilitator's Closing Remarks

There are many families that have been torn apart due to lack of trust. Couples should learn to trust themselves. In a church where multi-staff ministry is practised, pastors should trust one another. Between pastors and deacons, there should be mutual trust. In denominational establishments, mutual trust and acceptance are required for better working relationship.

Activity Period

  1. Do you, as a parent or office leader exercise a bit of trust in your children or subordinates? Consider today\'s lesson and make necessary adjustment.
  2. Pray for grace to exercise trust in and accept your children and subordinates.
  3. Pray also for wisdom and discernment not to do it foolishly.

title: understanding the concept of skill acquisition
message:
JULY WEEK 1

UNDERSTANDING THE CONCEPT OF SKILL ACQUISITION

HYMN: BH 49 (1991 ed.) Many and Great, O God

SCRIPTURE: Exodus 31:2-5

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, disciples should be able to:

  1. Briefly explain the concept of skill acquisition.
  2. Give the processes of skill acquisition.
  3. State the gains of skill acquisition.

ICE BREAKING PERIOD: Question and Answer

v Is it really true that there is mass unemployment in Nigeria?

v If yes, what is the way forward?

Facilitator's Opening Remarks

Thousands of graduates are produced annually from tertiary institutions, but the question is how will they be gainfully employed?

When there are excess workers in supply than there is in demand, then these happen: competition, unemployment, cheap labour, lack of basic working facilities, increase in social vices and hunger. Where supply of labour is more than demand, there is competition. Instead of the scenario to be positive, it is much more negative. The Church needs to sensitise members on the reality of economic downturn and the solution to it. Every disciple should make effort to have at least a skill and determine to put such skill into practice. We shall discuss skill acquisition generally in this lesson.

EDUCATION/INTERACTION PERIOD

  1. What Is Skill Acquisition?

    Skill acquisition is the ability to learn a skill, which can be intellectual such as learning to listen, speak, read and write or manual such as learning to build or make something. Skill acquisition has been described by many as the recipe for eradicating extreme poverty and hunger, thereby creating avenue for job and wealth creation. Encarta Dictionary (2009) defines skill as `the ability to do something well, usually gained through training or experience. Skill acquisition involves the development of a new skill, practice or a way of doing things usually gained through training or experience.\'\'

    Skill acquisition and employment generation have remained a focal point of the Nigerian government for long. Between 1986 and now, various administrations\' initiatives to promote self-dependence and self-reliance by creating opportunity for gainful self-employment have been profound. Gumbari, a member of the House of Representatives said, `\'Skills acquisition is the key in the fight for the elimination of hunger and poverty, reduction or elimination of joblessness in the society and reduction of crime through effective engagement of youths."

    Sharing Time: Define Skill Acquisition in your own words.

  2. Types of Skill

    The areas of focus for skill acquisition programmes include construction (carpentry, bricklaying, plumbing, electrical, painting, tiles laying, welding and glass cutting), personal care (hairdressing, barbing, soap making and cosmetology), automobile (auto-mechanic, panel work, vulcanising and air-conditioning), home appliances (refrigeration, television, sound system), fashion (tailoring, cloth designing, hat making, bead stringing), information and communication technology (computer studies, repair of mobile phones and software development), photography, printing technology, catering and hotel management.

    Sharing Time: A member should tell the class his/her understanding of the concept of skill acquisition?

  3. Process of skill acquisition

    The process of acquiring skill includes: having the dream, going for the training, remaining focused, practising the dream, getting a mentor and keeping evaluating your process.

    Sharing Time: Someone should share his/her experience of acquiring skill.

  4. Benefits of skill acquisition

    Learning one skill or the other is beneficial to both individuals and the Church. The following are the benefits in skill acquisition:

    1. For Individual

      v It helps the youths in the church to be self-reliant and independent.

      v It helps in developing a positive attitude toward work and labour.

      v It helps in gaining more knowledge.

      v It helps in building individual self-esteem.

      v It helps in developing entrepreneurial ability.

      v It can make a person become an employer of labour.

      v It makes payment of taxes easier and regular.

    2. For the Church

      v It reduces dependents in the church.

      v It helps members to contribute to the finances of the church.

      v It helps church members contribute cheerfully to missions.

      v It can help members have a right attitude to giving. It can help churches execute their projects.

    3. For the Nation

      v It increases tax acquisition to government.

      v It leads to financing community development projects.

      v It reduces crime in the society.

      v It reduces prices of goods and services.

      v It reduces poverty in the society.

      v It reduces hunger.

      v It reduces youth migration in search of greener pasture.

    Sharing Time: What should be adults\' attitude to skill acquisition by children?

Facilitator's Closing Remarks

To ameliorate the current economic crisis, the Church should promote and engage her members in skill acquisition. There should be programmes where people can be taught how to acquire at least a skill of their choice, even if they will pay but at a subsidised price. Therefore earnest effort must be put in place as a Church to reduce the present financial challenges of members in the church.

Activity Period

  1. Have you resolved to acquire at least a skill? What is your choice? Encourage someone in your community who is unemployed to acquire a skill.

title: learning about commerce
message:
JULY WEEK 2

LEARNING ABOUT COMMERCE

HYMN: BH 465 God of Grace and Glory

SCRIPTURE: Exodus 35:35

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, disciples should be able to:

  1. Define the term `Commerce
  2. Discuss how they intend to sell their products skills and to buy what they don\'t produce.

ICE BREAKING PERIOD: Question and Answer

v Do we have somebody here who produces all what he consumes?

v What do you need to buy or sell?

Facilitator's Opening Remarks

It is a waste of effort if disciples acquire skills and do not market their skills. This is the reason why learning commerce is very important when acquiring a skill.

EDUCATION/INTERACTION PERIOD

  1. What is Commerce?

    Commerce is the activity of buying and selling of goods and services. The system includes legal, economic, political, social, cultural and technological systems that are in operation in any country or globally. Thus, commerce is a system or an environment that affects the business prospects of economy. It can also be defined as a component of business which includes all activities and functions involved in transferring goods from producers to the buyers.

    Sharing Time: Some should tell the group what commerce is.

  2. Commerce as a Distribution Channel

    Commerce looks after the distribution aspect of a business. Whatever is produced must be consumed. To facilitate this consumption there must be a proper distribution channel. The channel is whereby the producer distributes to wholesale and retail outlets then finally to the consumers. This is why there is need for the knowledge of commerce to aid the smooth running of business.

    Sharing Time: What steps can we take as Christ's disciples to make goods and services accessible and affordable to the common man?

  3. Reasons for the Knowledge of Commerce
    1. Commerce tries to satisfy increasing human wants

      Human wants are never ending. They can be classified as `basic wants\' and `secondary wants.\' Commerce has made distribution and movement of goods possible from one part of the world to the other. Today, we can buy anything produced anywhere in the world. This in turn enables man to satisfy his innumerable wants, thereby promoting social welfare.

    2. Commerce helps to increase our standard of living

      Standard of living refers to quality of life enjoyed by the members of a society. When man consumes quality products, his standard of living improves. To consume a variety of goods he must be able to secure them first. Commerce helps us to get what we want at the right time, right place and at the right price thus improving our standard of living.

    3. Commerce links producers and consumers

      Production is meant for ultimate consumption. Commerce makes it possible to link producers and consumers through retailers and wholesalers and also through the aids to trade. Consumers get information about different goods through advertisements and salesmanship. The manufacturers are regularly informed about the likes and dislikes of the consumers through marketing research. Thus, commerce creates contact between the centres of production and consumption and links them.

    4. Commerce generates employment opportunities

      The growth of commerce, industry and trade bring about the growth of agencies of trade such as banking, transport, warehousing, advertising, etc. These agencies need people to look after their functioning. Increase in production results in increasing demand, which further results in boosting employment opportunities. Thus development of commerce generates more employment opportunities for millions of people in a country.

    5. Commerce increases national income and wealth

      When production increases, national income also increases. In a developed country, manufacturing industries and commerce together accounts for nearly 80 per cent of total national income. It also helps to earn foreign exchange by way of exports and duties levied on imports. Thus, commerce increases the national income and wealth of a nation.

    Sharing Time: Do we have reasons to hoard goods to sell it at higher price and make life unbearable to the masses?

  4. Selling Skills

    Emphasis in this lesson is that skill acquisition without marketing skill is useless and this calls for the knowledge of commerce. At this point you need to get your skill sold. You need to ask yourself, "How can I get customers?" "How can I sell in large quantity regularly?" Below are some tips that can help you have your skills sold gainfully:

    1. Understand what the buyer wants.
    2. Establish trust with the buyer.
    3. Communicate responsibly.
    4. Act on what the customer says.
    5. Demonstrate subject matter expertise.
    6. Tell really compelling stories about your product.
    7. Sell effectively over the phone.
    8. Be socially active with the targeted buyers.

    Sharing Time: What should be our attitude to commercial activities?

Facilitator's Closing Remarks

Acquisition of skill is important and knowing how to commercialise the skill for gains is more important. Here in this lesson, we have discussed what selling and buying really mean and how we can sell out our individual products. Let us therefore make effort to learn more about commerce so that we can be able to market our skills effectively to make profit.

Activity Period

  1. Do you have a skill already, even plaiting hair?
  2. Go ahead and start using the plaiting skill for money.

title: learning about information and communication technology
message:
JULY WEEK 3

LEARNING ABOUT INFORMATION AND COMMUNICATION TECHNOLOGY

HYMN: BH 59 He Leadeth Me! O Blessed Tho't!

SCRIPTURE: Proverbs10:14

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, disciples should be able to:

  1. Explain information and communication technology.
  2. List how the knowledge of information and communication help in actualisation of skill acquisition and its marketing.

ICE BREAKING PERIOD: Opinion Sharing

Let two members of the group explain briefly what they understand about ICT and another two to give reasons why it is important to learn about it.

Facilitator's Opening Remarks

A good way to think about ICT is to consider all uses of digital technology that exist to help individuals, businesses and organisations. ICT covers any product that will store, retrieve, manipulate, transmit or receive information electronically in a digital form. The world we found ourselves now is global and therefore our skill acquisition must be packaged in a way that maximises opportunities in an attempt to bring out good product for our customers. It is a quicker way to transact business, compute stress free financial analyses, transmit quotations and other information as per skill being advertised.

EDUCATION/INTERACTION PERIOD

  1. What is Information/Communication Technology (ICT)?

    ICT is an acronym for Information and Communication Technology. Really there is no specific definition for ICT. ICT (Information and Communications Technology) is an umbrella term that includes any communication device or application, encompassing radio, television, cellular phones, computer and network hardware and software, satellite systems and so on, as well as the various services and applications associated with them, such as video conferencing and distance learning. ICTs are often spoken of in a particular context, such as ICTs in education, health care, or libraries. So ICT is concerned with the storage, retrieval, manipulation, transmission or receipt of digital data. Importantly, it is also concerned with the way these different applications can work with each other.

    Sharing Time: Is Information and Communication Technology a blessing or curse to the world in terms of managing the skills acquired?

  2. Types of ICT

    In business, ICT is often categorised into two broad types of product:

    1. Traditional computer based technology These technologies are things you can typically do personally on computers at home or at work and these can be classified as:
      1. Standard office applications

        . Word processing: for letter and report writing.

        . Spreadsheets: e.g. MS Excel to analyse financials, calculations, create forecasting models, etc.

        . Database software: e.g. Oracle/MS SQL Server/Access to manage data in many forms from basic lists (e.g. customer contacts to catalogues).

        . Presentation software: e.g. MS PowerPoint to make presentations.

        . Desktop publishing: e.g. Adobe In Design/Quark Express/MS Publisher to produce newsletters, magazines and other complex documents.

        . Graphics software: e.g. Adobe Photoshop and Illustrator to create and edit images such as logos, drawing of pictures for use on websites or other publications.

      2. Specialist applications

        . Accounting package: e.g. Sage/Oracle to manage an organisation\'s accounts.

        · Computer Aided Design (CAD): to assist the design process. Specialist programmes exist for many types of design such as architecture, engineering, electronics and roadways.

        · Customer Relations Management (CRM): to allow business owners to better understand their customers by collecting and analysing data such as their product preferences and buying habits, etc. Often linked to software applications that run call centres and loyalty cards

    2. Digital communication technologies

      Digital communication technologies mean communication of data by electronic means. It is usually over some distance and often achieved via networks of sending and receiving equipment, wires and satellite links. It allows people and organisations to communicate and share information digitally. There are aspects of digital communications that you need to be aware of. These relate primarily to the two types of network and the ways of connecting to the internet. Let\'s look at these two briefly:

      1. Internal networks

        These are usually referred to as a Local Area Network (LAN). They involve linking a number of hardware items (input and output devices plus computer processing), together within an office or building. The aim of a LAN is to be able to share hardware facilities such as printers or scanners, software applications and data. This type of network is invaluable in the office environment where colleagues need to have access to common data or programmes.

      2. External networks

        This helps to communicate with someone outside your internal network. In this case you will need to be part of a wide area network (WAN). The internet is the ultimate WAN - it is a vast network of networks.

    Sharing Time: Is Information Communications Technology a blessing or curse to the effectiveness of church ministry and business?

  3. Benefits of ICT
    1. Greater efficiency throughout the learning system.
    2. Communication channels are increased through email, discussion groups and chat rooms.
    3. Regular use of ICT has a beneficial motivational influence on transaction.
    4. ICT facilitates sharing of resources, expertise and advice.
    5. Greater flexibility when and where tasks are carried out.
    6. Gains in ICT literacy skills, confidence and enthusiasm.
    7. Access to up-to-date information on targeted skill anytime and anywhere.
    8. Gains in understanding and analysing skills, including improvements in performance.
    9. Access to information via Google.

    Sharing Time: Mention two more benefits we can gain from ICT?

Facilitator's Closing Remarks

Acquiring knowledge and skill is an unending exercise which we should consciously pursue on a daily basis. This week we have tried to give training on ICT, an added skill needed to excel. ICT knowledge helps us in being a better entrepreneur, increasing our productivity and marketing. For students, acquiring skills on ICT help to improve quality of learning. As Christians, we are encouraged to create time to learn about it for a better living.

Activity Period

  1. What attempt will you make to practise ICT at your business organisation?
  2. Encourage someone in your neighbourhood to learn ICT.

title: learning about crafts
message:
JULY WEEK 4

LEARNING ABOUT CRAFTS

HYMN: BH 51 (1991 Ed) Creator God, Creating Still

SCRIPTURE: Exodus 31:3

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, disciples should be able to:

  1. Give the meaning of crafts.
  2. Explain the processes of craft making.
  3. Itemise the gains to align with the concept of skill acquisition.

ICE BREAKING PERIOD: Discussion

Someone in the class should explain his/her understanding of the creative nature of God. Who are made in God\'s image? Let a member tell the class, if humans can also create.

Facilitator's Opening Remarks

Today, as people face job losses, salary cuts, or other economic woes, it is worth examining whether or not you can do something extraordinary to make a living and to support your family solely by the efforts of your home craft business. In this study, your knowledge of how other things and processes work will improve. Through learning and developing a craft, one gains a fuller understanding of something very specific. Since this month\'s topics enable us to understand skill acquisition, it is therefore a necessity to know that skill can be endowed and that is called craft that is inbuilt skill. What is craft? What can we do with it? Let us check the answers together.

EDUCATION/INTERACTION PERIOD

  1. What is Craft?

    Craft is more of an inbuilt skill, style or application, than a tangible object. Craft is your technique; your brain\'s neural connections, sculpted over hours of practice. For instance, your craft is the way you apply paint to a canvas, how you think about a new musical composition or how you structure your written sentences in a short story or how you make your meal to give it a unique taste. Theoretically, one\'s craft can be applied to various mediums, such as writing and film directing. Often, there is not enough time in the day to apply it to more than one focus, but it is certainly possible. It is through working on that which you love that it can be matured over time. The fact is, everyone possesses craft. It is simply down to you to develop and nurture it over time. Understanding where your craft lies can make or define you. It can be a very powerful motivator to keep you going.

    Sharing Time: Someone should explain craft in his/her own words.

  2. What to Do with Craft
    1. Discover it

      A lot of people do not know the potentials they have, so the first thing is to discover it. How? You can do this through a checklist below:

      1. Things you do without stress.
      2. Things that give you fulfillment.
      3. Things you enjoy doing.
      4. Things you do without struggling.
    2. Increase your exposure

      Obviously the amount of self promotion and marketing your work receive will have an effect and it is assumed that you allow your craft to be seen by others at least occasionally. With regular commitment to your craft over time and as your skill improves, more people will talk about you, share your work for you and get you referrals and projects.

    3. Dedicate time to your craft

      The more time you dedicate to developing your craft, the more you will learn about what you are capable of. Time spent, even on just thinking about your craft, is time well spent. Spending focused time in this way will contribute greatly to knowing what you are capable of doing with your skill, as well as adding to the value you possess as a craftsman.

    4. Develop more credibility as an artist/skilled person

      Staying with a craft for a long time will show that you care for what you do. Caring in this way generates trust in those that follow and take an interest in you, which is very valuable.

    5. Learn from your mistake

      The more mistakes you make, the more you learn and know what to avoid in future. Making mistakes is one of the most important elements of developing craft. Craft is effectively the culmination of many mistakes that have guided you along the way. The more you know, the closer you are to reaching expert status in your field and being a valuable member of that industrial community.

    Sharing Time: Mention five different crafts you know. How can learning a craft improve your family economy?

Facilitator's Closing Remarks

Can you find an empty niche and create a product to fill it? This is so hard to do because people often focus on making crafts that they themselves like, without considering either (a) the competition for the product or (b) how many others share that interest. Sometimes a person becomes so enamoured of his or her own particular craft product that they either will not do the necessary market research to determine if their product is saleable, or they ignore what their market research tells them. Remember this: in order to make a living from your crafts, you must provide what customers want, not merely what you like making. An honest appraisal of product\'s marketability is important.

Activity Period

  1. What are your thoughts?
  2. Now, go and work on your craft, and stop making up excuses!

title: learning about fish farming
message:
JULY WEEK 5

LEARNING ABOUT FISH FARMING

HYMN: BH 50 (1991ed) God, Who Made the Earth

SCRIPTURE: Ecclesiastes 10:10

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, disciples should be able to:

  1. Define fish farming.
  2. Mention and explain different types of fish farming.
  3. List the requirements for fish farming, visit a fish pond and observe how it is being done.

ICE BREAKING PERIOD: Brainstorming

v Are there families that do not eat fish?

v Can we calculate together how many fish are eaten every week by individual families?

v Imagine if the fish were bought from your pond? Then you are a millionaire!

Facilitator's Opening Remarks

Without doubt from week one, attempt to find solutions to economic crisis have being our concern. For this last week in July, we want to see how we can improve our family economy through fish farming.

EDUCATION/INTERACTION PERIOD

  1. What is Fish Farming?

    Fish farming is a form of aquaculture. Fish farming is about raising fish commercially in tanks or enclosures for human consumption.

  2. Why Do We Raise Fish?
    1. Raising fish helps us make better use of our land and water.
    2. Raising fish enables family to have more to eat. The protein in fish will keep family members strong and healthy. Fish are tasty, like chicken, mutton and goat meat.
    3. Fish are raised for economic factor- i.e. to make profit.
  3. Types of Fish Farming
    1. Cage System

      This system uses cages that contain fishes in lakes, ponds and oceans. It is also widely referred to as off-shore cultivation. Fish are kept in the cage-like structures and where they are artificially fed and harvested. The cage method has made numerous technological advances over the years, especially in reducing diseases and environmental concerns. However, the number one concern of the cage method is fish escaping and being lost among the wild fish population.

    2. Irrigation ditch or pond systems

      The second method is irrigation ditch or pond systems of raising fish. The basic requirement for this method is to have a ditch or a pond that holds water. This is a unique system because at a small level, fish are artificially fed and the waste produced by the fish is then used to fertilise farmers\' fields. On a larger scale, mostly in ponds, the pond is self-sustaining as it grows plants and algae for fish food.

    3. Composite fish culture

      The third method of fish farming is called composite fish culture which is a type of fish farming that allows both local fish species and imported fish species to coexist in the same pond. The number of species depends on the size of the pond. It is sometimes up to six types of fish species in a single pond. The fish species are always carefully chosen to ensure that they can coexist and reduce competition for food.

    Sharing Time: Do you know any other types of fish farming?

  4. What do you need to raise fish?
    1. You will need a piece of land where you can build a pond, or suitable water areas to build pens or keep cages.
    2. You will need regular supply of water.
    3. Fingerlings to begin and food for your fish.
    4. You will need time to build a pond and to care for it regularly.
  5. Process
    1. Choose the soil- the soil where you build your pond should have enough clay in it. Clay soil holds water very well.
    2. Prepare your pond.
    3. Fertilise the water You can fertilise the water in your new ponds with compost made with plant and animal wastes. Stock your pond with baby fish.

      Feed the fish with food like small plants and animals grown in the green water. When the fingerlings begin to grow, they, too, will eat other kinds of food. You can give the fish in your nursery pond many things to eat. But you must be sure that this food is ground or cut very small so that the baby fish can swallow it. And gradually as the fish grows you give food like termites, tender leaves, waste of banana and cassava, grain mill sweepings, rice bran, beer wastes, cottonseed or groundnut cake, slaughterhouse wastes and so on . Note, as the fish grows the quantity of the food taking increases.

    Sharing Time: Discuss the possibility of the group being involved in fish farming.

  6. Harvesting Your Pond
    1. Do not take any fish out of your pond during the first five months. After five months you may catch a few big fish each week to eat with your family.
    2. When most of the fish are big enough it is time to harvest all of them. Usually, they will be big enough to harvest in about six months.
    3. Harvest the fish early in the morning when it is cool.
    4. Have some watertight containers ready to store live fish.
    5. The easiest way to harvest is by draining the water out of the pond.

    Sharing Time: What comes first, stocking the pond or getting the land?

Facilitator's Closing Remarks

Fishing business is lucrative if one can meet the requirements. Fishing is a skill like others. We can try the business and enjoy the goodies.

Activity Period

  1. Visit a fish farm to have the practical aspect of the lesson.
  2. Pray that God will open your eyes to discover what He wants you to do.

ROADMAP FOR DISCIPLES

The economic situation of our nation warrants every disciple to arise to his responsibility to find solution to the epidemic called unemployment. As at today, about 35 per cent of the population in Nigeria is unemployed and the Church cannot pretend not to be affected. Experts all over the world have written to support the importance of skill acquisition in redeeming the economy. Therefore we have to embrace skill acquisition in totality. Skill acquisition is no doubt what dying economies all over the world need for revival. Therefore it should be taught, understood and practised. One of the advantages is the creation of job. Unemployment is the epidemic we need to curb and totally eradicate. Skill acquisition is treated from different angles: fish farming, ICT knowledge, craft knowledge and commerce. We are encouraged to work on these lessons for a better standard of living.

title: characteristics and evaluation of postmodernism
message:
AUGUST WEEK 1

CHARACTERISTICS AND EVALUATION OF POSTMODERNISM

HYMN: BH 364 Yield Not to Temptation

SCRIPTURE: Romans 1:18-32

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, disciples should be able to:

  1. Mention the major characteristics of postmodernism and
  2. Carry out an assessment of it

ICE BREAKING PERIOD: Opinion Sharing

There are several "churches" today that argue against biblical Christianity. For example, they reject the belief that Jesus is the only way to salvation. Rather, they argue that God\'s love will end up taking all or at least the vast majority of people to heaven. What would be your response to such churches and their argument?

Facilitator's Opening Remarks

As a result of the civil wars and violent conflicts raging in the Middle East, hundreds of thousands of Muslims are migrating to Europe. As it turns out, thousands of them are converting to Christianity. In his reaction to this, a Reformed Church pastor in Amsterdam, the Netherlands made the following comments: "Conversion to Christianity is not promoted in our church, so we see very little of it"; and, "Everyone is a child of God." How would you describe this pastor\'s brand of Christianity?

EDUCATION/INTERACTION PERIOD

  1. Characteristics of Postmodernism

    The following are some of the major characteristics of postmodernism:

    1. Relativity of Truth and Denial of the Transcendent: Relativity of truth is the idea that there is no absolute truth or standard of morality and as such any claim of such is wrong. This is a sort of "anything goes" mentality. Postmodernism also believes that knowledge is dependent on one\'s perspective. There are various aspects of this feature of postmodernism. First, there are those who believe that reality is a social construction, that is, what we know as absolute reality, that is, God, is a mere human creation. Second, there are those who believe that if there was ever a God, that he is dead. Nietzsche (1844-1900) argued that "God is dead." Third, there are those who argue that there is no single unifying story or grand narrative that gives meaning and cohesion to life. And fourth, there are those who believe that though there is God, there is no single legitimate way of knowing him.
    2. Cultural Determinism: Postmodernism strongly believes that what individuals become is shaped by their culture which itself is created by language; hence, we are trapped in a "prison of language." Those who are aware of the nature-nurture debate in philosophy and psychology would appreciate this better. To postmodernists, nurture, especially one\'s culture, shapes his/her development, and the vehicle of that shaping is language.
    3. Rejection of Individual Identity: This is another characteristic of postmodernism. It claims that people exist as members of a group, not as individuals. In fact, in postmodernist thought, the individual has no place; it is the group that matters. It believes that groups should empower and assert themselves.
    4. Rejection of Humanism: Unlike in modernism where such concepts as human creativity, individual autonomy, and human priority over other creatures are accepted as norms and values, postmodernism stridently rejects them, claiming that they are the bedrock of human exclusion and oppression of other creatures.
    5. Power Reductionism: To postmodernists, all institutions, human relationships, and moral values are masks for power. According to them, all that modernists want is to control others. Likewise postmodernism rejects reason, because reason is simply an illusory mask for cultural power. Logic is simply a means of control.
    6. Revolutionary Critique of the Existing Order: In postmodernist\'s thought, the modern society needs to be replaced. It believes that modernism is too attached to scientific knowledge. Science, at least hard science, is too tied to the premise of absolute truth. Segmentation of society into various groups is the only action that will allow true cultural pluralism. There is a connection to Marxism in this characteristic. Marx\'s theory was that human society must change and that the result of any revolution would, by definition, produce a better society.
    7. Incessant Choice: A key feature of postmodernism is the prevalence of unending alternatives to choose from. Be it in automobile, fashion, electronics, cosmetics, travel, communication, etc., the range of choices before the individual is overwhelming. From supermarkets to departmental stores and shopping malls, the consumer is presented with a wide-range of options between and within brands through aggressive marketing techniques by companies. A direct consequence of this is consumerism and hyper-materialism.
    8. Globalisation: According to the Financial Times of London, globalisation refers to "the integration of economies, industries, markets, cultures and policy-making around the world. (It) describes a process by which national and regional economies, societies, and cultures have become integrated through the global network of trade, communication, immigration and transportation." A simple way of describing globalisation is that the world is like a global village wherein what happens in one part spreads to other parts, sometime like wildfire. Two recent examples are the Ebola Virus Disease (EVD) and the Zika virus. Globalisation is a major feature of the postmodern era.
    9. ICT Impact on Social Life: Historians of science and technology acknowledge two major global revolutions that have impacted human existence. They are the Industrial Revolution in the 18th and 19th centuries and the Information Revolution in the 20th and 21st centuries. The former lasted from 1760 to about 1840. The Information Revolution is now in vogue with Information and Communication Technology in its various forms trending. The use of computers and other digital instruments have come to stay. These are impacting social life in ways that were not imagined possible in the past.

    Sharing Time: How has globalisation affected your local area?

  2. Evaluation of Postmodernism

    Going through the above characteristics, we can deduce that postmodernism is a mixed baggage. It has the good, the bad, and the ugly. On the positive side, it has helped to show the lie in modernism\'s triumphalism and human-centredness. Modernism had this utopian notion of its superiority over preceding human epochs and other forms of thought. It believed that reason and the scientific method will usher humanity into socio-political, economic and technological paradise. It introduced a heightened sense of individualism and rejection of the non-corporeal and transcendent. The production and use of the atomic bomb in war and the negative impacts of other scientific and technological inventions helped to demonstrate that not everything about modernism or its claims were beneficial. To that extent, postmodernism is commendable. However, postmodernism poses some dangers of its own. Its emphasis on the group over and above the individual has the potential to stifle initiative and curtail individual rights. The other criticisms of postmodernism include its rejection of belief in grand narrative of life and of reason, as well as its encouragement of consumerism and materialism. From a religious and ethical point of view, the greatest disservice of postmodernism is its belief that the idea of God is man-made, that truth is relative, and that there is no absolute standard of morality.

    Sharing Time: From the above description of modernism and postmodernism, which of them do you think is more dangerous to the Christian faith?

Facilitator's Closing Remarks

Human historical epochs do not change the Word of God. Whether pre-modern, modern, or postmodern period, God\'s standard remain the same. Postmodernism is a reaction to the way things were before it came to be. We should align ourselves at all times with the word and will of God. One of the most dangerous teachings of postmodernism is the notion that morality is relative. This is contrary to the revealed will of God. So the disciple of Christ should be aware and always evaluate all human ideas with the Word of God.

Activity Period

  1. How true the argument is that one\'s culture alone shapes his/her development, exclusive of other factors?
  2. What are the implications of postmodernism to Christian living?

title: postmodernism and ministry to children
message:
AUGUST WEEK 2

POSTMODERNISM AND MINISTRY TO CHILDREN

HYMN: BH 511 Praise Him, All Ye Little Children

SCRIPTURE: Luke 15:12-32

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, disciples should be able to:

  1. Use the parable of the prodigal son to draw out the postmodernist mindset as it pertains to children.
  2. Identify ways to minister to them within the context of postmodernism.

ICE BREAKING PERIOD: Opinion Sharing

Children love cartoon shows and TV programmes. Let members mention some TV cartoon shows and identify their children\'s favourite ones. Why do children like cartoons and how do they impact their lives? If you are sitting in your living room with your children and while you want to watch your favourite programme, they want to tune to their own favourite TV cartoon show, what would you do?

Facilitator's Opening Remarks

Every child has a great capacity for evil or for good. They can be great instruments in the hand of the Lord for good or veritable weapons of destruction in the hand of the devil. God in Christ has a scheme to redeem children and reclaim them from the grip of sin but Satan has a strategy to keep them in bondage and under the control of the forces of darkness. The devil has always designed and/or utilised various irreligious and anti-God schemes, strategies and ideas in all historical epochs to destabilise God\'s programme, plan and purpose for mankind. Whereas not everything in each epoch is bad, yet he somehow finds a way to control and dominate them. This is true with postmodernism. An area that this is applicable is children. The character of the prodigal son in the parable named after him illustrates for us the life of a child controlled by a postmodern mindset. What is this mindset? It is a mindset of godlessness, licentiousness and avarice.

EDUCATION/INTERACTION PERIOD

  1. Five Basic Senses Every Child Needs

    Every child needs five basic senses if they are to function well and fully realise their potentials. The prodigal son manifests these senses in Luke 15:12-13. They include the following:

    1. A sense of intimacy: Where do I fit in? This is a question of relationships.
    3. A sense of identity: Who am I? This is the most crucial.
    5. A sense of initiative: What can I do? This is a question of purpose.
    7. A sense of innovation: What new thing can I do or where can I go? This is a question of adventure.
    9. A sense of choice: What should I do? This is a question of preferred alternative.

    Sharing Time: What can the Church do to be more proactive in Children Ministry to minister to children effectively?

  2. The Prodigal Son and the Five Senses
    1. When the prodigal son called his dad, `Father,\' he was expressing a sense of intimacy based on a father-son relationship. Every child needs a father in order to enjoy the full benefits of what it means to come from a home. Obviously there was an on-going relationship between him and his father, even though we do not know how cordial it was. Mind you, to be a father is not just a biological function through procreation. It is all embracing: procreation, provision, and protection. But the prodigal son abused the privilege of intimacy. This is the problem of abuse of inherent opportunity.
    2. When he told his father to give him the portion of his property that was due him, he was expressing his sense of identity: he knew his father and that his father was rich. Thus he surmised that a kid whose father was rich was also rich. But instead of waiting for the appropriate time to receive what belonged to him, he wanted it `quick-quick\' (speedily). By asking for his own share of his father's property he was doing the unthinkable. No one inherits his father\'s property while he is still alive! Thus it was as if he was saying to his father, "Father, why are you still alive? Since you have refused to die, give me my inheritance!" This is the problem of greed and impatience.
    3. When he gathered together what his father gave him, he manifested the sense of initiative. He was answering the question, what can I do? He had initiative, which is a good quality everybody needs in life. You would notice that he did not gather the things immediately his father gave them to him but took some days before doing so. That tells us that he was not an ignoramus. He apparently knew what he was doing. This is the problem of misguided initiative.
    4. When the Prodigal Son took his goods and went into "a far country," he was responding to the adventure drive within him. He wanted to explore his world, to try something new, to test the "greener" grass out there. Within every child is a latent pull to `a far country.\' Adventure and exploration are handmaids of discovery. What you dream you become; yet it must be at the right time and with the appropriate preparation. But this boy wanted to run before walking. This is the problem of premature independence.
    5. Life is full of choices and every choice has its corresponding consequences. So when the prodigal son "wasted his substance with riotous living," he was expressing his sense of choice. The qualifier, `riotous\' means that there was an alternative form of living. For instance, he could have chosen `righteous living\' rather than the riotous one. The Word of God cannot be broken, "There is a way which seems right to a man, but in the end it leads to death" (Proverbs 14:12). We can imagine some of the things that constituted the riotous life he indulged in: partying, fornication, drunkenness, avarice, gluttony, and all manner of latest music. This is the problem of self-indulgence.

    Sharing Time: How could children ministers train children to make positive use of their five senses within the context of a postmodern world?

  3. Ministry to Children within the Context of Postmodernism

    How should the church minister to children within the context of a postmodern world?

    1. The Church should be aware of the reality of postmodernism and its characteristics.
    2. The Church should equip and train her children workers with the relevant skills and competencies required to minister to children in a postmodern world.
    3. The Church should educate parents on healthy parenting in a postmodern world.
    4. We identified the following respective problems children of all epochs face but especially in our postmodern context: the problem of inherent opportunity, the problem of greed and impatience, the problem of misguided initiative, the problem of premature independence, and the problem of self-indulgence. These problems emanate from the abuse of legitimate senses children need in order to develop holistically. Thus the Church should synergise with families to remove the weeds from the wheat in children.
    5. The Church should be equipped and be actively involved in children deliverance ministry.

    Sharing Time: How can in-service training for children workers enhance in-depth growth for children ministry in this postmodernism?

Facilitator's Closing Remarks

The above five senses can be utilised negatively or positively. The prodigal son channeled his own wrongly because of the fact that the centrepiece of his sense of identity was selfishness. The prodigal son had no regard or place for God in his scheme of things until he reached the bottom of the futility of his wastefulness after "he came to his senses" when he realised that he had sinned against "heaven" (vv. 17-18). Every child needs to develop their senses of intimacy, identity, initiative, innovation, and choice. However, the spirit of postmodernism can corrupt these senses and thereby lead them astray. The greatest theological danger it poses is its argument against the existence of God which then carries with it the greatest ethical danger, namely, the idea that truth and morality are relative.

Activity Period

  1. How can parents proactively protect their children from the negative aspects of postmodernism?
  2. God gave everyone the freedom to make choices. Is there a limit to this?
  3. Every choice has its corresponding consequences. Substantiate this statement with some cases.

title: postmodernism and ministry to youths
message:
AUGUST WEEK 3

POSTMODERNISM AND MINISTRY TO YOUTHS

HYMN: BH 423 Arise, O Youth of God

SCRIPTURE: 2 Timothy 3:1-17

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, disciples should be able to:

  1. Relate Paul's prophecy about the last days in 2 Timothy 3:1-17 to the postmodernist mindset or spirit.
  2. Identify specific ways the Church can minister to youths in a postmodern age.

ICE BREAKING PERIOD: Discussion

There is so much love of money, self and pleasure among contemporary youths. Disobedience to parents is rampant, as well as hatred of the good. They would rather sing contemporary songs than classical music; they would rather watch a football match than go for Sunday evening worship or attend Bible Study; they know more about the latest smartphone than the latest Bible version; they know more about pop stars than the disciples of Jesus; and they would rather watch a favourite soap opera than read their books. Why do you think things are this way among our youths and what could be done to correct it?

Facilitator's Opening Remarks

Postmodernism is like a spirit with peculiar dynamics. Some of the dynamics are nothing but love of the world and its contents. What are the contents of the world? They are the lust of the flesh, the lust of the eyes, and the pride of life, all of which are transient (1 John 2:15-17). Love of the world is synonymous with friendship with it, which is tantamount to enmity with God (James 4:4). A section of the human society that is most susceptible to the influence of postmodernism is the youth. Consider the following characteristics of the contemporary youth: inquisitiveness, frequent change of church affiliation, high mobility, celebrity consciousness, fashion craze, entertainment and sport addiction, rejection of tradition, resistance to authority, addiction to the social media, and high ICT literacy.

EDUCATION/INTERACTION PERIOD

  1. The Last Days

    One of the passages of Scripture that best encapsulates what the postmodern spirit looks like among youths is 2 Timothy 3:1-7. Apostle Paul outlines the characteristics of what he calls "perilous times" of the `last days\'. Youths are more prone to them. That is why we want to use the passage to talk about postmodernism and ministry to the youth. In order to enhance our understanding of today\'s study, we have divided the discussion into three parts, namely, perilous men, pernicious (or destructive) techniques, and permanent termination. The line of reasoning goes this way: perilous men will use pernicious techniques to achieve their destructive aims but will eventually face permanent defeat. But let\'s first describe the meaning of two key words, `perilous\' and `last days\'. The word `perilous\' means extremely dangerous, hard, fierce, terrible (cf. Matthew 8:28); while `last days\' refers to the period of time between the first coming of Christ and His return. The characteristics of the last days outlined in the passage are reminiscent of the days of Noah prior to the Flood (see Genesis 6:5-7).

  2. Perilous Men (vv. 1-5)

    Perilous times are very dangerous as a result of the activities of perilous men. Perilous men are known by the following:

    1. The condition of their hearts: what they love self, money and pleasure.
    2. The words of their mouths: how and what they speak pride, arrogance, boasting and lies.
    3. The attitude of their lives: what they think blasphemy, treachery, rebellion and hypocrisy.
    4. The acts of their hands: what they do brutality and heartlessness.
    5. The nature of their faith: apostasy and empty religion with form but no content, or ritual without righteousness.
    6. The source of their doctrines: demons (1Timothy 4:1).
    7. The content of their teaching: heresies (1Timothy 4:2-3).

    We can simply describe the lifestyle, thoughts, attitudes, actions, and religion of perilous men as purely evil. It is like a virus of universal proportion engineered by the man of perdition. Evil men will even get worse as we get closer to the end time. The ultimate objective of perilous men is the destruction of anything godly, be it the people of God, the purpose of God, and/or the plan of God.

  3. Pernicious Techniques (vv. 6-7)

    In order to execute their wicked objectives as outlined above, perilous men mostly employ techniques that are opposite to their wicked characteristics. Thus their techniques or methods of operation are subtle, insidious, sinister, and serious. The techniques include craftiness, control, and insatiable but empty quest for knowledge. Why do they employ such techniques? So that they may not easily be noticed!

  4. Permanent Termination (vv. 8-9)

    The good news is that there is a terminal date for the activities of perilous men. It would seem as if the picture of the last days painted to Timothy by Apostle Paul was intended to instill fear and trepidation in him, but that is far from the truth; the opposite is rather the case. Thus he tells Timothy, "they will progress no further!" No matter how strong, well organised and/or formidable evil might be, there is a terminal date for its existence and operations. In order to drive home the point, Paul mentions two examples of evil men and the folly and futility of their wicked ways. They are Jannes and Jambres. The Bible does not mention the names of these two men but Jewish tradition has it that they were part of the Egyptian magicians that attempted to countermand God\'s miraculous intervention for the deliverance of His people from Egypt (cf. Exodus 7:11; 9:11). Paul describes these men in four ways:

    1. They resist the truth.
    2. They are disapproved regarding the faith.
    3. Their minds are corrupt.
    4. Their folly will be exposed in due course.

    These same attributes are akin to some of the characteristics of postmodernism such as the rejection of belief in the existence of God and of the idea of absolute truth. It is reassuring that postmodernism will not last forever.

    Sharing Time: In the light of the foregoing, how should churches minister to youths within the context of the manifestation of the postmodern spirit?

What churches need to do to minister to youth in the postmodern times:

  1. The Church should be aware of the dynamics of the contemporary times.
  2. The Church should adapt and/or modify its method and approach to youth ministry without compromising its message.
  3. Youths need adult mentors that would guide them by precept and personal example on the pathway to righteousness.
  4. The Church should equip youths with the necessary knowledge and skills to overcome the allurement of the negative aspects of postmodernism.
  5. Churches should design sporting competitions among youths.
  6. Churches should train their youths on how to use the social media to proclaim the gospel.
  7. Churches that are able should engage the services of trained youth ministers.

Facilitator's Closing Remarks

No matter how long the postmodernist mindset may prevail, it will not last forever. Perilous times and perilous men will not last forever. There is always a time limit for evil. This should give hope to the disciples of Christ wherever they may be. Though weeping may endure for a night, there is going to be joy in the morning.

Activity Period

One of the areas postmodernism is most evident among youths is their propensity to hedonism self-indulgence. Paul identifies three cardinal forms of this inordinate love love of self, love of money, and love of pleasure. An unholy alliance of these three forms of love is the basis of self-idolatry. What is wrong with them? In what ways do we see the manifestation of this self-idolatry among youths and how can they be helped to develop healthy forms of love?

title: postmodernism and ministry to adults
message:
AUGUST WEEK 4

POSTMODERNISM AND MINISTRY TO ADULTS

HYMN: BH 407 Loyalty to Christ

SCRIPTURE: Titus 2:1-5

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, disciples should be able to:

  1. Identify and describe the peculiar challenges adults face on account of postmodernism.
  2. Explain how the Church can minister to them as a result of those challenges.

ICE BREAKING PERIOD: Sharing

One day a man asked his driver to bring him his tablet from inside his car. The Samsung tablet was on the seat behind the driver\'s seat. The driver came back and said that he did not see any tablet. He asked him to check very well, that he was sure he kept it on the seat. The driver kept saying that there was no tablet on the seat. He had to tell him to bring `that thing\' on the car seat before the driver knew what he was referring to. To the driver the term `tablet\' refers to a medical drug.

Facilitator's Opening Remarks

Just as the youths of today are the children of yesterday, today\'s adults are the youths of yesteryears. Whatever may be their developmental stage or age bracket, children, youths and adults face the same challenges posed by postmodernism. The difference is only in the level of awareness and degree. So the Church is under obligation to minister to adults.

EDUCATION/INTERACTION PERIOD

  1. Pressures Posed by Postmodernism to Adults

    Postmodernism poses some challenges by way of pressures to adults. While some of them cut across different epochs but with certain peculiarity, others are totally unique to the postmodernist mindset. The following are eight of such pressures:

    1. The pressure of catching up with the dynamics of the period: We highlighted key dynamics of postmodernism in Week 1 of this study. Let\'s remind ourselves of the dynamics: relativity of truth and moral standard, cultural determinism, rejection of individual identity, rejection of humanism, power reductionism, revolutionary critique of the existing order, incessant choice, globalisation, the use of ICT and addiction to social life. Adults face the challenge of catching up with these.
    2. The pressure of the use of ICT: The average youth of today is ICT literate. They know how to operate the computer and the jargon associated with them. They know about CPU, monitor, mouse, URL, website, tablet, email, internet banking, gigabyte, RAM, android, memory, etc. Most adults of a certain age do not know what some of these terms mean, especially within the context of ICT where the words have unique meanings.
    3. The pressure of understanding the social media: A major area globalisation is evident is communication through the virtual world. There are so many available social media platforms which youths utilise on a 24/7 basis. You have Facebook, WhatsApp, MySpace, Instagram, Twitter, ChatON, Messenger, etc. Youths are constantly connected to them as they communicate with one another. The social media has changed and/or expanded the meaning of certain traditional words. For example, Facebook has redefined friendship such that one may have friends that he/she may not have met personally before but except through the media platform. Of course, this has brought in its wake certain challenges. Most adults of a certain age do not and may not be able to comprehend the social media, let alone use them.
    4. The pressure of managing the insatiable demands from their children: Children will always be children. One of the dynamics of our present time is incessant choices by the children. Yesteryears, the choice for a child would have been between wearing bathroom slippers and walking barefooted. Today, the choice is between one designer shoe or another; in times past it was between choosing eba and fufu or amala, today it is between fried rice/Indomie noodles; it used to be a choice between entering danfo/molue bus and a taxi cab to school, today it is between daddy\'s SUV and mummy\'s air-conditioned car. Adults struggle with such demands.
    5. The pressure of passing on cherished traditions to their children: Every society or culture has its cherished traditions. Due to its nature, the postmodern spirit challenges such traditions that were passed on across generations as it questions and/or suspects their foundation. Most adults struggle with explaining to young people the reasons they should adopt and abide by certain traditions whether in the community or the church. In times past, for example, most children would remain in the church of their parents as it is seen as a family heritage, but today parents may be in one church while their children may be in three different churches.
    6. The pressure of collapse of moral values: This is a corollary to the preceding point. If loyalty to age-long traditions is on the decline, commitment to traditional moral values would naturally follow suit. This in fact is one of the most tragic narratives of the present era. From our African perspective, some of the cherished traditions that have been bastardised are communal solidarity, respect for elders and constituted authority, chastity before marriage, marital fidelity in heterogeneous marital unions, hard work, merit, belief in the sanctity of life, and honesty. Today to abide by these values sometimes looks odd in certain settings. Thus the opposite of these values is what obtains. Consequently some adults are bewildered and sometimes in shock by this turn of events.
    7. The pressure of unstable job/source of income and of providing for their families: One of the major pressures faced by adults is that of unemployment, under-employment, loss of jobs, low or irregular income and the concomitant challenge these pose to them regarding providing for their families. The factors responsible for this bleak employment and income situation among the adult working class range from the global economic outlook to mismanagement of resources and corruption within nation states. Also, some of the factors are political while others are socio-economic. Thus, adults are faced with a double-edged sword namely, low or dwindling income in the face of skyrocketing inflation. They struggle with the load of providing decent accommodation for their families, paying school fees, providing food and clothing, and taking care of family health and medical needs.
    8. The pressure of social fragmentation: In the past, the average human society was stable and predictable in the normal ebbs and flows of life. It is no longer so. There is so much social fragmentation along ethnic, social, religious, political, professional, and communal lines that leaves people of goodwill bewildered. There is a `we\' versus `they\' mentality whereby those outside of one\'s circle of `we' are considered to be enemies that should be conquered, if not destroyed.
  2. Ministry to Adults in an Age of Postmodernism

    The above challenges faced by adults in our time call for outside-of-the-box thinking if they are to be effectively ministered to. What should the Church do in the light of this?

    1. Train and equip adults with the relevant knowledge and skills that would enable them withstand the challenges of the times.
    2. Encourage them to embrace ICT literacy, as much as possible. The Church may organise computer literacy programmes for the willing adults.
    3. The Church should train and teach adults to be role models and mentors to the youths. This is the essence of Paul\'s injunction in Titus 2:1-5 regarding ministry to adult members of his church. Older men are to be role models in temperance, respect, self-control, faith, love and endurance to younger men; while the older women by personal example and precepts are to guide the younger women to be good wives and mothers.
    4. Adults need to be encouraged to exercise hope in the Lord despite the way things are at the present time.

Facilitator's Closing Remarks

Postmodernism poses peculiar challenges to adults. Fortunately, such challenges are surmountable. With proper information and re-education, adults can understand some of the dynamics of our times as they pertain to computers and the digital world. With the way the world is going, and not very far from now, the condition of an adult that is not computer literate will be like that of an adult of today that cannot read and write. So, just as churches have adult literacy programmes, they should develop adult computer literacy programmes for their members.

Activity Period

  1. Let us highlight with examples some of the dangers associated with the use of the social media.
  2. How can parents monitor what their children are doing on their computer and on social media?
  3. How many members of the group have active email addresses?
  4. Let someone with basic ICT literacy explain to members how to open and use an email address.

ROADMAP FOR DISCIPLES

There are four lessons in this unit. It is possible that before this unit\'s lesson you might not have heard about postmodernism or if you had, you might not have been able to describe what it means and how the Church can minister to the various age groups in the church within its context. But now you have known, it is incumbent on each disciple to apply the lessons learnt to their situations. Individuals, families, groups and the Church should be willing to re-evaluate their ministry strategies in the light of contemporary challenges without diluting the Gospel message. As a disciple of Christ, can you explain the meaning of postmodernism in simple terms? How much are you aware of postmodernist influences around you and in your own life? A major feature of our times is the prevalence of ICT usage. As a child of God how can you be computer-literate without being computer controlled? How can you utilise computer literacy for the promotion of the gospel?

title: an agent of smooth relationship
message:
SEPTEMBER WEEK 1

AN AGENT OF SMOOTH RELATIONSHIP

HYMN: BH 465 God of Grace and God of Glory

SCRIPTURE: Ephesians 4:25-32

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, disciples should be able to:

  1. Explain what smooth relationship with others means.
  2. Demonstrate how to build smooth relationship as agents of transformation.

ICE BREAKING PERIOD: Group Discussion

In a world where individualism is threatening the unity of the Church, how can we build good relationship?

Facilitator's Opening Remarks

Good and cordial relationship is more than something we do hypocritically. It goes beyond the words of mouth. It is something we need to consciously cultivate and engage in as a body of believers. Establishing cordial relationships does not come automatically. It comes through intentional investment of our time, talent and treasure.

EDUCATION/INTERACTION PERIOD

  1. What Is Smooth Relationship?

    Smooth relationship is when a group of people, members of a family, organisation or community develop connection based on mutual respect, trust, honesty, support, equality, and good communication. This smooth relationship allows members of the group to feel supported and connected but still feel independent. Relationship is a necessary part of healthy living, but there is no such thing as a perfect relationship.  Relationship could be smooth when everyone involved is ready to give and take and expresses their feelings without any inhibition. One who would want a smooth relationship should be ready to respond to group members\' feeling positively. Smooth relationship gives us several other benefits: our life is more enjoyable, people are more likely to go along with changes we may want to implement, and we are more innovative and creative. Furthermore, it brings us a great deal of happiness, fulfillment, strong connections with loved ones; friends, church members, and colleagues. Smooth relationship equally allows us to be at our best physically, spiritually, socially and psychologically. It may also help members to obtain good advice, guidance, love and support. 

    Sharing Time: How can we recognise the difference between self-centered and genuine relationship?

  2. Why Do We Need Good Relationships?

    Human beings are naturally very sociable. We enjoy the company of others and crave positive interactions and meaningful friendships. To some extent good relationships are just as important for our survival as air, water, and food; this can explain why our health and happiness suffers when our relationships go wrong. Therefore, the better our relationships work, the happier and healthier we are going to be. It has been observed that people with satisfying relationships are likely to have fewer health problems and live longer. In contrast, those who do not have many social connections tend to show signs of depression and cognitive decline. Good relationship is necessary because it supports the health and well-being of people.

    In the family life, having good relationship with spouse and children enhances peace and is helpful for progress and development. Good relationship between husband/father and wife/mother sets example for their children to emulate.

    In the church life, having good relationship with members and pastoral leadership fosters healthy growth and makes way for kingdom expansion. Likewise, in the workplace, having a good relationship with colleagues and others in the professional circle boosts productivity and is valuable for career development. Being on good terms with your boss means you are more likely to be considered if a new position opens up. There is also a sense of freedom. Rather than spending our time and energy overcoming obstacles associated with relationship issues, we are focused on opportunities and personal development.

    Sharing Time: Do smooth relationship make life better within multi-ethnic society?

  3. Foxes that Destroy Good Relationships

    There are different foxes that render relationships ineffective and problematic and if they are not addressed as early as possible, it can lead to emotional and mental problems. Therefore, some of these foxes are discussed as follows:

    1. Criticism: is the act of expressing disapproval and of noting the problems or faults of a person. A remark or comment that expresses approval/disapproval of someone or something can both be positive or negative. It may be good criticism if it is done in a friendly manner to build up rather than in opposition to pull down which can damage a smooth relationship.

    2. Gossip: is one of the major relationship killers. Gossiping about a situation will only stirs up animosity and cause mistrust and suspicion between the parties involved.

    3. Jealousy: A lot of relationships have been destroyed due to jealousy. Jealousy can make people try to destroy another\'s reputation while they remain the saint. Jealousy, if not properly addressed, can lead to many other sins. Jealousy is a thing of the mind and when it starts, it leads to hatred and hatred leads to so many other sins against humanity.

    4. Contempt: It is talking down on somebody, insulting or acting superior. Not only does this lead to relationship breakup, but can cause illnesses for the recipient of the contempt.

    5. Defensiveness: Defensiveness starts when one easily feels attacked, blamed, controlled, manipulated, victimised and unfairly dealt with;usually when a loved one brings up a problem, dissatisfaction or difficulty.  Defensiveness, a natural reaction to being criticised can be in two forms namely; counterattacking or acting like an innocent victim and whining.

    6. Deception: is an act of a trick or scheme used to get what you want. An example is when you trick your sister to agree to do all your chores for a month; deceiving others to have your way. Any other way that prevents the truth of one\'s actual self and life to be known is involved here. 

    Sharing Time: How can we relate well with difficult personalities who are always ready to spoil relationship?

  4. How to Handle the Foxes that Destroy Relationship

    All relationships are unique, but there are several characteristics that can signify strong, healthy connections. Relationship needs proper care and attention of those who are involved. There is need for adjustment, good understanding and compromise. If we can follow certain steps, then it can be easier and comfortable to have strong relationships among relations, with spouse, family members, friends, neighbours, classmates, co-workers and so on.

    1. Communication is at the heart of all relationships. All relationship needs good communication. Your relationships will be richer if you make an effort to keep in contact with those around you. Being honest and open with others allows you to connect deeply and build long lasting bonds.

    2. Love nourishes your relationship softly and carefully like a mother takes care of her child. We must not allow ego, hatred and evil thought to come into our relationships. Nurturing our relationship is one of the most powerful secrets of smooth relationship. Be real and unique and let your partner also be like that. The freshness of relationship makes relations rejoice and get better.

    3. Trust is very important in any relationship and once it breaks then no one can bring it back. Lack of trust will create problems in relationship and sometimes may cause break up. Truthfulness makes relationship smooth and great. Relationships are built on trust, which is essential for good communication and forming strong bonds. Without trust, relationships are unlikely to survive. 

    4. Sincerity is the hallmark of a smooth relationship and it determines if it will go far and grow. It is the absence of pretence and makes the other parties involved depend on each other.

    5. Admiration is about the story you tell yourself about your partner and how you appreciate one another even when your partner is not there. Admiration can help to show whether your relationship is working or not. Strong supportive relationships rely heavily on mutual respect, as it fosters understanding of each other\'s needs and values. 

    Sharing Time: How can you carry on your relationship within the context of segregation, and nepotism?

Facilitator's Closing Remarks

All relationships have their ups and downs, but some causes of break ups are a lot deeper and take a greater observation than what you may think. Another important fact is that a lot of people act without even realising the damage they are causing. Smooth relationship with others is the environment to foster good character development.. It is the environment and the context in which true self-discovery becomes discerned and known.

Activity Period

  1. What can you do to build better relationships at home, church, and workplace?
  2. How good is your relationship with other church members?

title: the salt of the earth
message:
SEPTEMBER WEEK 2

THE SALT OF THE EARTH

HYMN: BH 457 Send the Light

SCRIPTURE: Matthew 5:13

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, disciples should be able to:

  1. Recall the various uses of salt
  2. Apply their knowledge of the uses of salt to help the community of faith and the society at large.

ICE BREAKING PERIOD:

Why is it sometimes difficult for some of Christ\'s disciples to influence their society when it comes to standing for biblical principles?

Facilitator's Opening Remarks

Salt is one of the basic elements with which human body is made. Salt, which has lost its flavour is of no use. While salt preserves and sweetens, it has no value when it has lost its usefulness. In other words, salt makes its impact felt in food we eat and when it\'s no longer useful or loses its importance then it is thrown away. No wonder Jesus Christ told His disciples that they are the salt and light of the world. Disciples of Christ are to make a difference as salt makes a difference in cooking. The primary purpose of any disciple is to impact his world to the honour of the Master who has called him/her to follow Him.

EDUCATION/INTERACTION PERIOD

  1. Salt: a Metaphor

    Jesus Christ used salt as a metaphor to compare believers for a reason. Salt is a dietary mineral, used for flavouring and preservation. It is needed by all known living creatures. If abused, it can be harmful. However, it is also bad not to eat salt because it regulates the water content in our bodies. Jesus used salt to describe how Christians are needed to bring balance and hope to an otherwise dying world. It is interesting that when the early Christians were persecuted in the Roman Empire, the Christian apologists pleaded for tolerance saying that the society continued to exist because of Christians. In essence they were saying that Christians upheld the good values in life; they worked for reconciliation and peace and they prayed for the empire and its well being.

    Sharing Time: Of what benefit is the salt if it loses its flavour or value? Similarly, of what significance is a disciple of Christ who makes no impact in his/her community or environment?

  2. Characteristics of Salt

    1. Salt is palatable. It adds taste to the food we eat. Salt brings out flavour. As a Christian, there should be something about you that brings a little more meaning into people\'s lives and provides zest and flavour to their activities.

    2. Salt is precious. In Jesus\' day, salt was a rare commodity and thus had enormous value. Greek aristocrats had a custom of exchanging their slaves with salt. If the slave did not meet the purchaser\'s expectation, that slave "was not worth his salt," hence the expression, "He is not worth his salt." As salt, followers of Jesus are extremely precious "commodities" in this world. We should be worth our salt for Jesus\' sake.

    3. Salt penetrates the food into which it is added. It permeates the entire food. Though you may not see it with your naked eye, it does its work silently and effectively. Followers of Jesus worth their salt will not want to toot their own horn or make a lot of noise, but they will quietly and effectively diffuse the flavour of the gospel to many communities around them.

    4. Salt preserves and thus prevents decay.  There were no freezers in Jesus\' day as we have today. The only way to preserve food, such as meat, was to salt it away and thus prevent it from decay. What Jesus is saying to His followers, is that we are that "palatable, precious, penetrating preservative that prevents decay." And we are that "salt of the earth" to protect people from the stress of living and toiling, working at their economies, building their communities, and developing cultures.

    Sharing Time: What do you do when salt and sand are mixed together? Is it possible to reverse this process? Can this salt be made salty again?

  3. Ways to Be Salt of the Earth

    1. By Functioning Like Seasoning Agent: Salt spices things up. It improves the taste of the food it comes in contact with. Christian values should improve the nature of the society and make it better. Food without salt is tasteless. A disciple of Christ\'s is one who by his anointing brings a new flavour of love, joy, peace, forbearance, courage, hope, care, goodness, faithfulness, gentleness, kindness and self-control into the life of others.
